The most common method of homicide was through the use of sharp instruments, with knives being responsible for the majority of these cases (29 out of 29). It is noted that 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs at the time of the offense. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasizes the importance of continued efforts in education, enforcement, and community support to address violent crime and alcohol misuse. Claire Baker, Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman, expresses caution about the statistics, pointing out previous instances where figures were revised and highlighting the increase in sexual crime and violent crime in Scotland.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, becoming the first team to lose to Sunderland this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's only goal, their first in three games. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over Bournemouth's inability to capitalize on their chances, despite having scored six goals against Hull City before this match. They were defeated by Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe's goals, and although Steven Pienaar was sent off for Sunderland, Bournemouth couldn't find an equalizer. Howe stated that while the loss was difficult to accept, moving on and learning from it was crucial.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's stance on immigration and the policy of detaining migrants who attempt to reach Australia by boat. Abbott argues that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," which involves taking migrants to offshore processing camps before they are resettled elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," of "dubious legality," and at odds with Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Abbott defended the policy, stating it has successfully stopped illegal boat arrivals in Australia. He also compared the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, saying IS militants "boast about their evil," while Nazis tried to hide their atrocities. This comparison drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups, who argued that IS crimes cannot be compared to the Holocaust. Abbott later defended his comments, saying he was not in the business of ranking evil, but maintained his comparison.

The passage discusses the escalating conflict in Aleppo, Syria, where the Syrian government, with support from Russia, has intensified attacks on civilians and rebel groups. The US has accused Russia of failing to uphold its commitments to the ceasefire and has suspended bilateral talks with Russia aimed at sustaining the cessation of hostilities. The US blames Russia for targeting critical infrastructure, including hospitals, and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians. In response to the US decision to halt the talks, Russia expressed regret and accused the US of not fulfilling its own agreements. The situation in Aleppo has led to hundreds of civilian deaths, with 250,000 people trapped in the eastern part of the city. The US and Russia were scheduled to meet in Geneva to coordinate air strikes against terrorist groups but have suspended these talks. The US has also withdrawn personnel from a joint implementation center that was to be established. Despite the breakdown in talks, both sides have agreed to continue discussing counter-terrorism operations to avoid unnecessary clashes.

The passage discusses a proposal by the Policy Exchange think tank suggesting that the UK government could raise £4.5bn annually by selling high-value social housing. This money could be used to build between 80,000 and 170,000 new social homes. The proposal suggests that social housing would still exist in expensive areas but in reduced quantities, with the argument being that no one has an inherent right to live in the most expensive parts of town. The think tank's director suggests that this could reduce the number of people on the social housing waiting list by about 500,000. The Prime Minister's official spokesman indicates that councils have the freedom to sell high-value social housing if they choose to do so, as a way to manage their housing stock more efficiently. Labour, however, criticizes the proposal, arguing that it would force hard-working families out of neighbourhoods and create segregated communities. They propose alternative solutions, such as using a bank bonus tax to fund affordable homes and employing unemployed builders to boost the construction industry. Critics of the sell-off idea express concern that it would lead to the dramatic erosion of mixed communities and the creation of ghettos. The passage also mentions that the coalition government cut the Labour government's social

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old man from Swansea, died at his home last week. Swansea is experiencing an epidemic of measles, with 942 cases reported. The cause of death could not be conclusively determined as measles during an autopsy; an inquest is scheduled for Tuesday to allow further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for measles. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated at Swansea's Morriston Hospital for asthma and was discharged a few days before he became ill with a rash. He went to see an out-of-hours GP on April 17th with a full-body rash but not on his arms. The next morning, he was found dead in his flat. Public Health Wales confirmed laboratory tests showed a diagnosis of measles, but further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. The family is puzzled about how Mr. Colfer-Williams contracted measles since none of his close family members, including his three-year-old vaccinated daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Loweswater Avenue in Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving an attack on a boy under the age of 16. The incident is reported to have occurred in 2001. Mr. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court later.

The passage describes a football match between Gateshead and Guiseley. Gateshead and Guiseley are both teams competing in the National League. Guiseley took the lead early in the match with a goal from Jake Lawlor, who scored after a throw-in found him to net an empty net goal. Gateshead's Liam Hogan made a crucial save, and Wes York had a shot saved by Guiseley's Jonny Maxted just before halftime. In the second half, Gateshead equalized through Wes York, who scored after a mistake by Guiseley's substitute Derek Asamoah. The match ended in a 1-1 draw. Key points include Guiseley's early lead, Gateshead's equalizer, and the fact that both teams have been performing well recently, with Guiseley unbeaten in five matches and Gateshead not having lost in nine National League matches.

The summary of the passage is as follows: Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club Bristol City, plans to increase the stadium capacity by replacing two stands instead of building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to a town green application. The decision was confirmed at a shareholder meeting on Tuesday and was previously approved by Bristol City Council in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown stated that they will sign a section 106 agreement soon and wait for a judicial review period of six weeks. If the judicial review does not occur by March, the redevelopment plans will proceed, starting in May.

The passage discusses a recent event where Cuadrilla Resources, a company involved in shale gas drilling (fracking) in the UK, suspended its drilling operations after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake occurred. This earthquake was the second in two months and was centered in Poulton-le-Fylde. The British Geological Survey (BGS) noted that the quake's location and mechanism were similar to a previous one in March. The BGS is monitoring the fracking process as a precautionary measure due to the potential for induced seismic activity. Cuadrilla Resources has halted operations to analyze data collected by the BGS and will consult with relevant authorities and experts before deciding whether to resume drilling. The passage also mentions the controversy surrounding fracking in the US, where environmentalists claim it contaminates drinking water, making it possible for tap water to ignite. However, a recent UK parliamentary committee report recommended supporting the process with tight regulation and good industry practice. The BGS states that any process injecting fluids into rocks at depth can cause seismic activity, and the latest quake occurred about 2 km from the drilling site.

Angus Carpenter, a piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner while busking in 2015. He was cleared of two other fraud charges. Sgt Chris Gaynor testified that Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting money for the charity, but Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and had permission from the Hillsborough Justice Campaign chairman, Kenneth Derbyshire, to design and display the banner. The banner featured the eternal flame and the word "justice" and Carpenter stated it was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive anyone. Carpenter is known as a busker at Anfield match days and is familiar to the Hillsborough Justice Campaign. He will be sentenced in January.

Summary: Ipswich Town secured a crucial victory against Queens Park Rangers with a comprehensive 3-0 win at Portman Road. Grant Ward opened the scoring with a scuffed shot which rolled into an empty net after QPR's Alex Smithies mishandled a clearance. Tom Lawrence then doubled the lead with a calm finish from a Cole Skuse pass. Ipswich's Christophe Berra headed wide and Skuse fired a volley straight at Smithies, but the visitors rarely threatened. Luke Varney completed the scoring after Smithies failed to clear a ball, and despite late pressure from Rangers, the three points moved Ipswich up to 14th in the Championship table. QPR boss Ian Holloway was disappointed with his team's performance, especially after the second goal, and conceded his defenders should have helped their keeper. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised Luke Varney and Jonathan Douglas, highlighting Varney's performance as an example of what he wants from his team. The win lifted Ipswich up four places to 14th, while QPR slipped to 15th in the table.

The passage describes Will Wells, a 23-year-old player, who performed impressively in the T20 Blast last season. He scored a total of 373 runs with an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. Wells expressed excitement about the direction the club is heading, attributing the positive environment to the coaching staff and the elite performance culture they have established, which motivates the players to be part of the team.

The passage describes a rugby team, the Reds, who have achieved a second consecutive win by defeating Chinnor 29-12. The victory places them fifth in the National Two South league. The performance was particularly strong from the front row and front five, who made over 70 tackles collectively. The upcoming games include seven teams ranked below them in the league standings, as well as the league leaders, Old Elthamians. Despite the win, the coach, Churcher, believes there is still room for improvement and emphasizes the importance of building on their last weekend's performance to avoid it being a wasted effort.

The passage describes the arrest of a man named Nazrul, also known as Nazu, by the police in Kolkata (Calcutta) for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun. This incident sparked outrage in India and led to protests in various cities. It is the sixth arrest in connection with the crime, with police having identified eight suspects in total. Five of these suspects have already named Nazrul as the rapist. The police arrested Nazrul based on a tip-off that he was returning to Kolkata by train after fleeing to Bangladesh following the attack, captured on CCTV. Earlier in May, Milon Sarkar was arrested and described as the leader of the gang responsible for the attack on the convent in Ranaghat town on March 14. During this attack, money was stolen and the building was ransacked before the nun was raped inside the convent.

The passage discusses the reasons behind changes in consumer purchasing habits, highlighting technological advancements and economic factors. It mentions the introduction of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports as significant influences on what consumers buy. The passage also points out that the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, founded by Robert Opie, explores these changes through an interactive video. This video allows users to delve deeper into how ownership and rankings of major UK brands are evolving. The passage advises viewers that the video may not work on older browsers and suggests viewing a non-interactive version of the content for compatibility. Additionally, it provides links to supplementary information on the topics covered in the video, such as an article on what China owns, tips on freezing food, and a BBC Good Food Annual survey ranking the top 20 consumer brands in the UK.

The passage describes two incidents where individuals were scammed by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked into giving money to someone who claimed to be fixing her internet issues. Seven days later, a woman in Stranraer fell victim to a similar scam, with the caller saying there were problems with her internet and gaining remote access to her computer to steal money. The police emphasize the importance of caution when dealing with cold calls asking for remote access to one's computer, warning that such actions can lead to substantial financial loss. They advise that banking details should never be shared over the phone, as legitimate banks and businesses do not request such information.

The passage describes the hiring of Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, by the Featherstone Rovers club in the Championship. He has joined for a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. Duffy will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday. Chairman Mark Campbell expressed excitement about Duffy's leadership, praising his accomplishments at Swinton despite challenging circumstances. Duffy, who played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during his 16-year playing career, has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton Lions.

The passage describes an incident where a Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The purpose of their mission was to respond to an emergency involving a rider who had sustained head injuries and was lying unconscious on wet sand. The rider was treated by the crew and the medic before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further medical care.

The decision to improve global flight tracking was made at a UN conference in Geneva on Wednesday. The conference was held to address the weaknesses in the current tracking system, which relies on ground-based radars. MH370's disappearance highlighted these weaknesses, as the current system leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. Representatives from over 160 countries decided to allocate a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC), organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU). This new system, ADS-B, will allow real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. The decision comes after Malaysia's communication minister urged the ITU to find new ways of transmitting flight data in real-time following MH370's disappearance. The ITU Secretary-General Houlin Zhao stated that the agency had responded quickly to the global community's expectations on the issue. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in case of an emergency.

The passage tells the story of Julian Hernandez, a boy who disappeared at age five and was recently identified as an 18-year-old living with his father in Cleveland, Ohio. Bobby Hernandez, the boy's father, 53 years old, was arrested on October 30, 2021, for allegedly tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The arrest is related to Julian's disappearance in 2002, when Bobby claimed to be taking Julian to pre-school but never returned. The FBI received a tip in October 2021 that led them to believe this teenager might be the long-missing child. After working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, they confirmed Julian's identity. His mother has been notified of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez is currently being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on a $250,000 bail, charged with tampering with records and potentially being responsible for Julian's disappearance. Authorities had suspicions at the time of the disappearance that Bobby might have been involved.

The passage describes an incident where a fire occurred at a site on Duncan Street on 2 March, leading to disruptions in train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire. The fire service noted that the company was "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, but they had raised concerns to the EA about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA, after considering these concerns and conducting joint visits with fire safety officers, decided to revoke the environmental permit for the company, effective on 7 August, barring any appeal. The company is required to remove all waste from the site by then. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, which are linked to the situation in Ukraine's Crimea region. The first bill would allow Crimea to become a part of the Russian Federation if a referendum or a request from the territory's leaders is made, citing the strong separatist and pro-Russian sentiment in the area. Many Russian citizens already reside in Crimea, particularly in Sevastopol, where a majority hold Russian passports. The second bill aims to facilitate the issuance of Russian passports, removing previous requirements such as paying a state tax and having a residence in Russia. This is framed as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians, referencing a 'brown threat'—a reference to World War II fascists. The bill proposes a quicker process for Ukrainians to obtain Russian citizenship, including the ability to apply at Russian diplomatic missions and become citizens after two months instead of a year. Notable Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea to support the initiative.

The passage discusses McLaren's rich history in Formula 1, highlighting their past successes, including 12 drivers' world championships and eight constructors' titles. It recounts their dominance in the 1980s with drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, who won 15 out of 16 races in 1988. The team experienced a decline after that, culminating in a $100m fine and being stripped of the 2007 constructors' championship due to an illegal possession of Ferrari data. The article also mentions the 'lie-gate' scandal in 2009 and the team's struggles with their Honda power-unit partnership in recent years, which has led to a significant drop in performance. Despite these challenges, Ron Dennis, the team principal, remains optimistic about McLaren's future, believing that success is imminent. The passage ends with the hope that McLaren can break Mercedes' dominance and return to winning ways, especially with Fernando Alonso, who joined the team in 2015 in pursuit of a third world championship.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was fatally shot at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27, 2018. He was 44 years old and from Everton. Two men aged 29 and another aged 32 were arrested for questioning. Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market and was getting into his car when he was shot. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. They are looking for a silver Volkswagen Polo that left the scene quickly and traveled along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Merseyside Police is also seeking the public's help in identifying individuals captured on CCTV near the meat market who have not yet come forward. These people may have information crucial to the investigation.

The passage discusses several ways to celebrate Christmas online, including virtual church services, a fantasy game with Bible-themed quests, a viral nativity story told through social media updates, a modern Christmas ad by a Christian charity that was rejected by cinemas for being too religious, and a Manga version of the nativity story available in multiple languages. It highlights the increasing use of digital platforms by religious groups and organizations to reach and engage with audiences globally, particularly during the festive season. The passage also touches on the creative and innovative approaches being used to convey spiritual messages, such as using popular culture references like Star Wars to relate to contemporary audiences.

The passage discusses an eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale concerning a proposal to develop 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts have given conflicting testimony on whether building on the common land would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales expressed difficulty in concluding the replacement land is of equal value but did not oppose the development overall. A developer's ecology report suggested a "net gain" in biodiversity with the proposed enhancements to nearby habitats, which the Gwent wildlife trust disputed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and ultimately, Welsh government ministers will decide whether the development can proceed.

The passage discusses the reaction of Chechen Muslim clerics to a report by Novaya Gazeta, which alleged that more than 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three reported deaths. The clerics' response, issued on April 3, warned of retribution against the "true instigators" of the report, which they deemed an insult to their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. Novaya Gazeta, the newspaper that published the report, urged Russian authorities to protect journalists from potential reprisals. The report also mentioned the authoritarian leader of Chechnya, Ramzan Kadyrov, who denied the allegations and claimed there were no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechen spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, echoed the call for retribution, stating that "Allah will punish those who slandered the whole Chechen nation and Chechen Republic's clerics." The passage also notes the context of previous murders of Novaya Gazeta reporters in Chechnya and the ongoing persecution of the LGBT community in the region, as well as the efforts by the Russian LGBT Network to help victims flee the area and the potential for an International

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, partners with Fresh Start Housing, a charity, to find housing for single homeless men. The charity refers clients to Investing Solutions and private landlords. Investing Solutions places several unrelated people in one house and charges housing benefit for each person, increasing the total payout. This practice allows Investing Solutions to make a significant profit, as demonstrated by their high earnings from housing benefit in London boroughs like Wandsworth. One of their tenants, Nigel McCann, describes living conditions in their properties as unsuitable and substandard, with issues like lack of heating, hot water, rats, and damp. Wandsworth Council, which has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1 million in the past two years, states they have a team to ensure the private rented sector is safe and affordable. Crisis, a homeless charity, calls this practice a "new low." Fresh Start Housing is an independent charity with its own board of trustees, and Investing Solutions claims the bulk of rents are passed to private landlords who own the properties. The charity asserts they have housed 788 homeless people since their founding and 222 in the last 12 months. The Department for Communities and Local Government states local authorities are responsible for ensuring rigorously safe-guarded taxpayer money

The British team, featuring London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence and NBA player Ben Gordon, led most of the game against the Dutch team. However, the Dutch team overtook the British in the last 10 minutes of the game to secure a victory. The British coach, Joe Prunty, emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity throughout the Eurobasket qualifying campaign. Despite the loss, Prunty was pleased with Ben Gordon's performance, particularly his three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter.

The passage discusses the negotiation between Conor McGregor and the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) regarding the glove size for their upcoming boxing match. McGregor, who is a former UFC champion, wants to use 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves required for fights at 154 pounds. The NAC has rules that allow for lighter gloves (8oz) for fights between 135 and 147 pounds if a waiver is submitted and approved by the commission, considering health and safety. Mayweather, McGregor's opponent, had initially stated he would use 8oz gloves but had not submitted a waiver. The NAC executive director, Bob Bennett, has reviewed various factors, including McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz and his ability to take a punch, to justify approving the fight. Despite some criticism from boxing personalities, Bennett believes McGregor is capable and the fight is justified. The NAC will debate the glove size issue on August 16 before making a decision.

Fleet Street was synonymous with the nation's biggest newspapers for decades, being the home to many national and provincial newspapers. It was once a very important place through which most of the public received its information, with the first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, published there in 1702. The street was known for its many bars and pubs, frequented by journalists and printers. It was the pinnacle of a journalist's career, with nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers having offices within a half-mile radius. The death of journalism was announced too soon by some London tour guides, as journalists like Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith were still working there. The street was famous for its history, with tales of smoke-filled newsrooms, typewriters, and lorries delivering large rolls of paper to printing presses. The departure of its last two journalists should be marked, but looking forward, not backwards. The move of newspapers to cheaper computerized printing technology and new locations, such as Wapping, led to the gradual decline of Fleet Street's newspaper industry. The buildings that once housed newspapers have since been repurposed, with the site of Mirror Group Newspapers now being the headquarters of Sainsbury's supermarkets

The passage discusses J.K. Rowling's experiences with online abuse and her reactions to it, particularly in response to her political donations and tweets. Rowling tweeted about feeling her personal line had been crossed by abusive comments, especially after donating £1 million to the campaign against Scottish independence. She faced criticism for her donation in 2008 to the Labour party as well. In 2014, she donated the same amount to oppose Scottish independence, leading to a flood of criticism and abusive tweets from some Scottish National Party (SNP) supporters, whom she called "bullies." Rowling blocked abusive users and made it clear she felt no obligation to protect the SNP's image. Despite the hostility, she acknowledged having had positive interactions with other SNP supporters and discussed shared political views. Rowling humorously responded to a suggestion that her books should be burned by joking she would bring marshmallows. The SNP won a significant majority in the 2015 UK election, taking 56 of 59 Scottish seats.

The passage discusses a study by University of Edinburgh researchers that examines the relationship between poverty, crime, and the juvenile justice system in Scotland. Key findings include:

1. Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action compared to their better-off counterparts who commit the same crime.
2. Living in poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls.
3. Poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts.
4. Poverty exacerbates the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors are considered.
5. Extreme poverty increases the chances of both being a victim and a perpetrator of crime.
6. Boys are three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts on average.
7. Girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely as girls from affluent households to be involved in violent crime.
8. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 to understand changes in their behavior and lifestyles.
9. The Scottish government has stated that Scotland is becoming a safer place to live, with crime at a 41-year low.
10. Despite the overall decrease in crime rates

The passage describes the events surrounding the stabbing death of Karl Haugh, a 25-year-old man, in a laneway on the Marian estate in Limerick, Ireland, early on Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh, 25, from Island View in Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm in relation to the incident. He has been remanded in custody and is scheduled to appear in court again next week. Two other men arrested in connection with the killing were released without charge, with their cases being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. During the incident, it is alleged that Walsh and two other men entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee around 1:00 AM looking for Haugh. A fight broke out involving Haugh, another man, and the three accused, during which weapons, including knives and golf clubs, were used. Haugh received a fatal stab wound to his back. Gardaí (Irish police) arrived to find knives and golf clubs at the scene. Haugh was taken to Limerick University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 6:00 AM. A knife handle and blade with blood on it were recovered from the scene. The judge noted the tension in the area

The passage describes an incident where Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted a controversial comment about Tom Elliott, an MP and former member of the UDR (Ulster Defence Regiment). The tweet insinuated that Mr. Elliott harassed people and shot others during his UDR service. Tom Elliott, who served in the UDR for 10 years between 1982 and 1992, has a clear MoD record. The tweet was brought to Elliott's attention by Ann Travers, a victims campaigner, and Arlene Foster, a DUP assembly member who is set to become Northern Ireland's first minister. Phil Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and later issued an apology, admitting that his tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation." The High Court case resulted in Mr. Justice Stevens reserving judgment on the compensation amount. Additionally, the insurance firm that indemnifies MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan for any compensation and costs in this case, leading to Flanagan challenging this decision in a separate court action. Tom Elliott expressed satisfaction with the court's decision, stating that he has been totally vindicated and that Phil Flanagan admitted the comments were untrue. Elliott expressed disappointment that the case took 19

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 employees, has increased its production of sweaters to meet the demand generated by the successful launch of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range in January. The company, which has historical roots dating back to 1874, was acquired by Benny Hartop in November 2020. In addition to its new brand, the firm has experienced growth in its business of supplying customers who sell the garments under their private labels. Hawick Knitwear operates in various European countries and also exports to the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The company's production has surged from about 7,500 sweaters per week last year to 9,500 sweaters per week currently, to accommodate the increased demand from both private label clients and its own brand. The managing director, Benny Hartop, attributes the success to the dedication of the company's staff and expresses optimism about the future.

The passage describes the case of Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady who was seriously injured outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He claims he was blinded by the setting sun and does not remember whether the traffic lights were red or green when he struck Mrs. Blackburn. The incident occurred as Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. The prosecutor stated that Mr. Wright's Volkswagen Golf did not stop for the red light and hit Mrs. Blackburn. Mr. Wright expressed his sorrow for what happened to Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses an anti-submarine warfare (ASW) exercise conducted by NATO, focusing on the hunt for a German U-boat named U33. This exercise is a response to increased Russian submarine patrols in the same waters and highlights a gap in Britain's own ASW capabilities. The U-boat, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf and carrying 28 crew members, is trying to avoid detection by 10 NATO warships, including a Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland. The goal for U33 is to target the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker.

Surface ships face the challenge of locating an invisible enemy in vast ocean stretches, akin to finding a needle in a haystack. The USS Vicksburg's crew scans the horizon for a periscope, while sailors listen to sonar and sensor data in a darkened room. Lieutenant Colin Ryan, the anti-submarine warfare officer on board the Vicksburg, acknowledges the difficulty in detecting submarines but remains cautious about confirming the identity of unidentified submarines.

Russia has a significant submarine fleet, including advanced nuclear and diesel-electric submarines, and has recently launched what it claims is the "quietest submarine in the world." Peter Roberts, a former Royal Navy officer

The passage describes the dire situation in South Sudan, where violence has led to a massive refugee crisis. Since July, when violence spread to previously peaceful southern Equatoria states, 340,000 people have fled to neighboring Uganda. The refugees, who include 200,000 who fled Syria this year, are escaping ethnic killings, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines. Nelson Ladu Thomas and Otima Amos recounted their harrowing escapes, detailing the violence and atrocities they witnessed. Uganda, despite being overwhelmed by the influx of over a million refugees, provides immediate aid to the newcomers, allocating them land and shelter within 36 hours. However, the country is beginning to struggle with the resources needed to support such a large number of refugees. The UNHCR's senior emergency coordinator, Nasir Abel Fernandes, calls for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence against civilians. The passage ends with a poignant example of resilience and trauma, as a young girl named Patricia Mercy performs a poem about her loss and suffering.

The passage describes the upcoming boxing match between McKenzie, a 38-year-old boxer, and Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on November 12 for the English super-middleweight championship. McKenzie has a professional boxing career that began in 2013 after he quit football two years prior. He has an eight-win, one-draw record from his nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, who is a former three-time world champion.

The passage describes a £330m investment by the coalition government for new NHS facilities across England, with £33m allocated for the construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital. The current hospital, built in 1813, is described as cramped, outdated, and in poor condition, with Matron Sue Taylor highlighting the need for a modern facility to improve patient well-being. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for mobile scanners. Funding for the project will come from the NHS and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014, located on land at Bowers Lane, contingent on planning permission. The passage discusses a study that found women are just as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to receive one. The study concluded that there was no support for the "reticent female" theory and suggested that the difference in pay rise acceptance rates could be due to discrimination against women. They argue that retired people should undergo regular driving tests and that there should be a driving assessment in a car with an instructor to accurately assess their driving capabilities. Michael's brother Simon suggested that the government should introduce a test to prevent accidents caused by drivers who are no longer safe on the road. The passage also mentions that currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licences every three years through a self-assessment form without a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated that there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age and that they remove driving entitlements if a driver's medical condition affects their ability to drive safely. Caroline Abrahams from Age UK emphasized the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible, as driving

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence. Women have reported debilitating side effects, leading to concerns about the safety of the implants. Two patients on the original review group resigned in protest over what they perceived as a watered-down report. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will examine the review process and its conclusions. The review recommended against offering the procedures routinely and suggested patients be given information to make informed choices. It also recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an outright ban, the health secretary stated the government lacked the power to do so, leaving it to the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, faced criticism for failing to unite the panel members around the report's conclusions. Some panel members, including patients who suffered complications, resigned in protest. The passage also mentions that reporting parts of the final report were removed and that more than 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone the procedure with many experiencing painful and debilitating complications. Legal action is ongoing against health boards and manufacturers.

The passage discusses Laura Muir's breaking of Eilish McColgan's 25-year-old 5K indoor record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Muir's time was 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds, which was 14 seconds faster than McColgan's previous record. Initially, there were concerns raised by McColgan regarding the legitimacy of Muir's record due to the race format, which was a mixed 3K race where Muir was the only competitor to complete the 5K distance. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would undergo ratification but is expected to be confirmed as official. McColgan expressed excitement about Muir's achievement and confidence in her ability to win world medals. She also compared Muir's race strategy to her own record-breaking race, where she ran solo and lapped other runners, including a young Paula Radcliffe. McColgan expressed pride in seeing her record broken by a fellow Scot and emphasized Muir's potential to achieve even faster times and win medals.

William Fox-Pitt, aged 47, competed in the Rio Olympics just 10 months after being in an induced coma following a fall. He was riding Chilli Morning and was leading after the dressage phase. However, he incurred several time penalties during the cross-country phase, dropping to 21st place. In the final show-jumping phase, Fox-Pitt delivered a faultless performance, but his medal chances were already ruined. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Fox-Pitt finished 12th overall.

Andy Murray won a four-set match against Fabio Fognini, securing victory with a 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 win on Centre Court at Wimbledon. Murray, the second seed, reached the fourth round with a match point at 20:57 BST. The match was tense and featured several set points for Fognini, who is the 29th seed. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday after Konta's win. Murray won despite not playing his best tennis, showing resilience and fighting spirit to overcome Fognini. He is pleased to advance to the next round and is looking forward to a break and working on his game before facing Paire.

The passage describes an incident at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, Northern Ireland, where paramedics were called to a sudden death at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived later to find several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was subsequently closed for three months by Limavady Magistrates Court. Two individuals, Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The defense solicitor acknowledged that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to and that the premises had not been run properly, with the bar running well into the morning of the incident. The judge expressed concern over the lack of custodial sentencing options and fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000 due to their "appalling records" and the severity of the case.

The passage describes Mike Nesbitt, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, delivering a speech to launch his party's manifesto titled 'Real Partnership'. He emphasized the importance of partnership over domination in politics. The speech was a response to the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, with the Ulster Unionists wanting the election to serve as a referendum on how it was handled. However, the focus shifted to the Ulster Unionists following Nesbitt's comments about the need for partnership.

When questioned about Danny Kennedy, a senior party colleague who distanced himself from Nesbitt's remarks, Nesbitt responded positively, indicating that it reaffirmed his belief that Kennedy was listening. Nesbitt stood by his comments, stating he had no regrets and was focused on the future rather than past mistakes. He encouraged voters to support the Ulster Unionists and then choose candidates who would do the right thing for their communities.

Nesbitt expressed a preference for entering Stormont Castle (the Northern Ireland Assembly) with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin, despite the controversy his remarks about transferring votes to the SDLP had caused. He spent time in unionist areas where he received support for his stance.

The passage discusses a legislative move by the Justice Minister Claire Sugden in Northern Ireland. She confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aligning Northern Ireland's legal stance with that of England and Wales. This motion aims to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, both posthumously and for living gay and bisexual men who were convicted. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', after Alan Turing, this initiative also allows living men to apply for pardons. The motion in the assembly is expected to include provisions for both posthumous and living pardons. The minister secured executive agreement to propose this motion to the assembly, aiming for equal treatment of gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales. The minister emphasized that this approach will allow for quicker implementation than through a traditional assembly bill. The motion will now proceed for consideration by the assembly.

The passage describes Yvonne Muir, a 23-year-old athlete from Kinross, Scotland, who set a new Scottish record in the 1500 meters race. Her time of 4:19.12 seconds surpassed the previous record of 4:22.60 set by Yvonne Murray in 1994. Muir's performance also placed her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's record of 4:17.57. After finishing fifth in last year's World Championships, Muir now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She expressed her satisfaction with the record, stating, "I am really pleased to get that Scottish record. It means a lot to me." Muir's recent victory in an 800m race in Montbeliard, France, preceded this achievement. She is aiming to secure a spot for Great Britain in the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro by performing well at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26. The passage also mentions that Muir is a veterinary student, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.

The passage describes a selection of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as "most excellent" for their water quality. The core pieces of information include:

The summary is: The passage presents a collection of pictures showcasing 26 beaches in Scotland, which have been distinguished as having the highest water quality, earning them the title of "most excellent" beaches.

The passage discusses the conclusion of a legal inquiry into the death of Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian intelligence officer who died in 2006 after being poisoned with polonium-210 during a meeting in London. The inquiry's barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko. He suggested that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot, with "reasons aplenty" for wanting to harm or kill Litvinenko, who had defected to the UK and made accusations against the FSB, the successor to the KGB.

Horwell argued that the use of polonium-210, which caused Litvinenko's death, indicated some form of Russian state involvement. He emphasized that this did not implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin personally or suggest he gave the order, but there were various possible motives for the murder. Litvinenko's defection and public accusations against the FSB and Putin himself could have been seen as acts of treachery by the Russian government.

Horwell also mentioned that Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death, and the use of polonium left a "trail of pol

The passage discusses the appointment of Steve Smith as the permanent Test captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke who has retired. Smith, at 26 years old, already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team due to Aaron Finch's injury. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. The selectors highly regard Smith's talent and believe he is the right man for the job. Smith has played in 32 Tests for Australia, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Clarke's retirement was confirmed after Australia lost the Ashes to England. Smith previously captained the team in three Tests against India last summer when Clarke was injured. The selectors chose Smith as Clarke's successor due to his performance and leadership qualities. Warner, despite his history of disciplinary issues, has been chosen as vice-captain due to his maturity and development into an important senior figure in the team. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval.

The passage discusses Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron's stance on LGBT+ rights and his refusal to directly answer questions about whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin. Farron is passionate about LGBT-plus rights and wants to defend equal marriage, extend marital rights for transgender people, and eliminate the spousal veto that prevents transgender individuals from marrying without their spouse's consent. He voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about protecting individual liberties, but he supports equal access under the law for all people regardless of their sexuality. Despite being asked three times during a Channel 4 News interview, Farron consistently refused to give a direct answer on whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating that "my firm belief is we are all sinners."

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, North East England, in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. The plant is being repurposed by Accord Healthcare, with the intention of rehiring many of the former Sanofi employees. Accord Healthcare is a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, producing and distributing over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries worldwide. The move is expected to have a "extremely positive" impact on the local area, with Newcastle City Council's leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, praising the development for strengthening the science and healthcare sector in the region and providing a boost to the local economy by creating highly skilled jobs.

The passage describes the departure of three senior staff members from the local council: Richard Ellis, who is leaving at the end of his contract; Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland, who are going under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, views these departures as indicative of the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff. Richard Ellis has previously served as the interim director of corporate governance and has been acting as the deputy chief executive for several months. Ciaran Monaghan is the head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland is in charge of human resources and customer services. The council chief executive, Angela Scott, expresses gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems. Martin initially announced he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing, just not on Hondas this year. He won't race at the North West 200 or the Ulster Grand Prix due to team-mate John McGuinness' crash at the North West 200 and the Fireblade's uncompetitiveness at the Ulster Grand Prix, respectively. Martin expressed his dissatisfaction with the TT, stating it was a "bloody disaster" aside from testing the Mugen bike. He prefers to focus on racing classics and "oddball" events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The APC's Muhammadu Buhari defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll, and will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost control of key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, one of the states hardest hit by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold onto Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC won in Lagos state, which has not been under the same party as the president since 1999. The PDP will need to introspect and rebuild after its significant losses, partly due to widespread corruption allegations and failure to curb Boko Haram. The elections were marred by violence, but were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes for Nigeria's democracy.

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. Mighty accuses both companies of turning a blind eye to unsustainable practices in the palm oil industry, which contribute to the annual haze affecting several countries, including Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. These practices include slash-and-burn clearing for palm oil plantations in Indonesia, particularly in the Riau province and parts of Kalimantan.

Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, claims to have a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy. However, Mighty's report suggests that Olam has created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies," which may be contributing to the haze and unsustainable practices. Olam only agreed to release the names of its 14 suppliers after resisting calls to do so for some time.

The report also implicates Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, suggesting that Singapore's state fund may be inadvertently supporting practices that contribute to the haze. Temasek has dismissed the allegations, stating that it supports no

The passage describes a restaurant that began serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced in 2016, allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they were outdoors. The restaurant's offering is described as a "right dog's dinner," and the information is presented with a light-hearted tone, using the phrase "check out this clip" to encourage viewing. The core pieces of information are:

2. The reason for the introduction of this new menu item: a new law permitting dogs to eat at restaurants, with the condition that they must be outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury and has only been able to play from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent, who has been out with a groin injury, could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a return to the starting lineup after coming off the bench to score a late equalizer against Huddersfield.

The ban on YouTube in Pakistan was lifted because Google, which owns YouTube, launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed the reopening and welcomed YouTube back on Facebook. The ban was imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." Google has a process for the PTA to request the removal of offending content, but YouTube will not automatically comply with such requests. Google has a Transparency Report to document government requests for content removal. The local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka were launched last week.

The passage discusses the upcoming election to replace Sepp Blatter as president of FIFA, highlighting a controversy involving Domenico Scala, who heads the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee. Gianni Infantino, one of the presidential candidates, is also Swiss-Italian, similar to Scala. In 2015, Scala stepped down from his role due to a conflict of interest because he shared nationality with a candidate, Sepp Blatter. This time, Scala argues there is no conflict of interest because Blatter is not a candidate, and there are five candidates instead of two. Musa Bility, the boss of the Liberian Football Association, threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Bility argues that the same process should be followed as in 2015 to ensure fairness and integrity in the electoral process, given the turmoil FIFA has faced. The election is set for 26 February in Zurich.

The passage describes the tragic incident involving two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, who were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road. They were working in a paint-spraying area when the incident occurred around 09:00 BST on Monday. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. The cause of the incident is believed to be a flashover explosion, which is the result of a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, leading to a fire-ball effect. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham stated that significant progress had been made with forensic inquiries and obtaining witness statements. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has sent inspectors and electrical safety experts to gather evidence and investigate the incident.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf during the Nations Cup. Morocco was banned from the 2017 qualifying draw but the ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Morocco was punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears. Tunisia and Morocco have resolved their disputes with Caf, allowing Tunisia to participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will play against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. Tunisia could set a record by reaching their thirteenth straight Nations Cup if they advance to the finals.

The passage describes a post-match incident involving Manchester City and Chelsea during a game at the Etihad Stadium. The game ended with Chelsea winning 3-1. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off from Manchester City for violent conduct. Aguero received a four-match ban for his second dismissal this season for a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz. Fernandinho was also involved in a scuffle with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas and was given a three-match ban. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charges.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon, South Wales, aimed at improving the diagnosis of cancer in its early stages. The scheme focuses on family doctors who examine patients with cancer symptoms but no clear signs. The initiative was prompted by a visit to Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer detection rates. The concern in Wales is the delay in diagnosis due to a lack of clear symptoms, leading to a lengthy process where family doctors refer patients back and forth for various tests. The pilot aims to streamline this process by having family doctors refer suspicious cases directly to Cardiff University Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days. The plan involves seeing up to 40 suspected cases per week and providing various tests. Currently, only 35% of suspicious cases in the Cwm Taf area receive a diagnosis. The initiative also includes setting up a similar clinic in Port Talbot Hospital as part of a broader screening program by the South Wales Valleys Health Board. The scheme was developed over 12 months following a visit to Denmark, which had established diagnostic centers due to concerns about cancer detection rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of Cancer Network Wales, states that the scheme will both streamline the referral process and accelerate the diagnosis

England secured a comprehensive victory over Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning by an innings and 180 runs. They made 589-8 declared in their first innings and then declared on 173-1 to set Pakistan a massive target. Joe Root was the standout performer, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, earning him the man of the match award. He also took four catches and bowled a spell that helped dismiss Pakistan for 234 in their second innings. England captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, saying it was "as good an innings as I've seen." Coach Trevor Bayliss noted that Root had worked hard to improve after making mistakes in the first Test. The pitch at Old Trafford did not help Pakistan much, as they were bowled out in 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott described the Pakistan team's performance as a "breakdown" and predicted that England would win the series. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq admitted that their batting was poor and that they lacked confidence and shot selection. The third Test at Edgbaston starts on August 3.

The British and Irish Lions are in New Zealand with Warren Gatland as head coach and Rob Howley as interim coach. Forwards coach Shaun McBryde will take over head coaching duties for the third time, having previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde is excited about the opportunity to lead the team again and believes it will be an exciting challenge. The Welsh Rugby Union is in discussions to appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and provide an opportunity for growth and development.

The passage describes a football match between Hull City and Southampton, which ended with Hull City winning 2-1. Key points include:

- Hull City scored first through a penalty by Charlie Austin in the sixth minute.
- Southampton took the lead with a goal from Robert Snodgrass in the 61st minute, followed by an assist for Michael Dawson's goal in the 64th minute.
- Hull City equalized in the 68th minute with a goal from Snodgrass and another from Dawson.
- In the final minute of added time, Southampton's Sofiane Boufal cleared a ball off the line to prevent a Hull equalizer.
- Hull City ended their six-game losing streak with the win, while Southampton celebrated a famous victory over Inter Milan in the Europa League earlier in the week.
- Hull City's win came despite early injuries to their strikers, which gave Snodgrass an early opportunity to play and make an impact.
- Hull return to action with a trip to Sunderland on November 19, while Southampton host Liverpool on the same day.

The crash occurred at 14:15 BST on the B1191 road in Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. A motorcyclist was killed in the collision with a tractor driver, who was not injured. The B1191 road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle as a result of the incident. Lincolnshire Police is appealing for witnesses to come forward.

The passage describes a political crisis in Macedonia, where President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power allegations revealed by covert recordings. This decision was made ahead of early elections in June, with the stated intent to "put an end to the agony." However, his move was criticized by both the opposition and EU officials, with the EU Enlargement Commissioner stating that it was not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis began in 2015 when opposition leader Zoran Zaev started releasing a series of recordings that allegedly show government ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Zaev accuses the government of widespread corruption, including wiretapping, mismanagement of funds, dubious criminal prosecutions, and cover-ups of killings. The government denies the accusations and accuses Zaev of destabilizing the country.

The passage discusses the managerial situation at Swansea City following the dismissal of Bob Bradley. Curtis and Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club's first choice for the new manager is Paul Clement, an ex-Derby manager. The passage also reflects on Swansea's history, highlighting their promotion to the Premier League in 2011 and their reputation for playing attractive, possession-based football. Curtis, a former player and current assistant manager, believes the team has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. He attributes this to frequent changes in management and the loss of key players. Curtis emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League, reminding new signings of Swansea's rise from near-bankruptcy to the top tier of English football, as depicted in the documentary "Jack to a King." He is confident in the current squad's ability to stay up but acknowledges the challenges, particularly in comparison to clubs like Newcastle United.

The passage discusses the outcome of a football match between Dagenham & Redbridge and Leyton Orient. Dagenham & Redbridge, who were relegated from League One to the National League in the 2020-21 season, secured their relegation with a defeat to Leyton Orient. Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona scored for the Daggers, but Armand Gnanduillet's goal sealed their relegation. Meanwhile, Orient needed the win to keep their play-off hopes alive. The passage also provides context about Dagenham & Redbridge's historical context, including their first entry into the Football League in 2007 and their return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously took them from the Conference to League One. It highlights the struggles of Dagenham & Redbridge this season, particularly their poor goal difference and attack, with Jamie Cureton being their top scorer. The passage concludes with comments from the managers of both teams regarding the match and the challenges faced by Dagenham & Redbridge.

The passage describes how Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp announced that Steven Gerrard, the former captain of Liverpool, will return to the club in February as a youth coach. This will be Gerrard's first job since retiring as a player in November 2015 after a 19-year career. During his time at Liverpool, Gerrard won multiple major trophies, including the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup, three times each. After leaving Liverpool at the end of the 2014-15 season, he joined LA Galaxy in the MLS. The passage also mentions that Gerrard had been linked with the managerial position at League One side MK Dons but decided against it as the opportunity came "too soon" for him. Additionally, Gerrard is working towards obtaining his Uefa A coaching license, which is necessary for managing in the Premier League. Klopp praised Gerrard's ambition to become a manager and believes he has a bright future ahead in football management.

The summary of the passage is: McManus scored first, followed by a deflected strike by Ross Forbes to double Morton's lead. Kyle McAusland's shot pulled Alloa back, but McManus and Denny Johnstone scored later to ensure a comfortable win for the hosts.

The passage discusses a situation where Ofsted inspectors found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three illegal schools in Birmingham. These schools have since been closed, and their owners are under investigation for running illegal schools. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern that this could be just the "tip of the iceberg" and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization. The government is consulting on plans to regulate places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week to prevent such illegal operations. Currently, any place teaching children for more than 20 hours a week must register as a school. Some places, described as part-time education centers or "flexi schools," are operating legally to support home-educated children but are being scrutinized for potentially operating as illegal schools. Sir Michael criticized officials for providing confusing advice to proprietors of the closed schools, which delayed their closure. The government has set up a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. The focus is not limited to Muslim communities but will apply to any religious group operating in unsafe or unhygienic conditions. Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh. It is one of several proposals to open a whisky distillery in the region since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes is excited about the potential to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence." The gin's production is smaller than other proposed distilleries, fitting into a cowshed. Lilliard Gin aims to capture the local flavor palette of the Teviot valley. The distillery is a companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the same site. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The name reflects the landscape and the distillery's female production team.

The passage describes the tragic death of Harry Whitlam, who was killed by Gary Green when Green, who was driving a vehicle on private land, reversed into him. The incident occurred at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013. Gary Green, who was 51 years old at the time, was more than twice the legal driving limit. He had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before getting behind the wheel. Harry Whitlam's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and emphasized the importance of not driving under the influence. She stated that her family had been changed forever by the loss of Harry, her youngest son. Gary Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others, prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private land. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) described Green's behavior as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, the 27-year-old Uruguayan striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches after his appeal against a four-month ban was partially successful. The ban, which prevented him from participating in any football-related activities, has been lifted for training purposes, and he will now be able to train with Barcelona's first team. The public presentation of Suarez as a new Barcelona player will take place at the Camp Nou on Monday.

Suarez's ban from organized matches still stands, but he is now permitted to take part in all football-related activities, including attending matches and participating in promotional events. He will continue to serve the remaining eight competitive international matches of his nine-match ban, with his competitive Barcelona debut expected to be against Real Madrid in El Clasico on October 26.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) ruled that the original ban was too harsh, as it prevented Suarez from training, which would have affected his development after the suspension ended. However, Cas upheld the ban on playing organized matches.

The passage describes a unique and humorous event where couples compete by carrying each other over a 380-meter course that includes hurdles over haystacks, a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania. The couple attributed their victory to a week of intensive training, running around an athletics track near their home. The event is open to all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. After their win, Richard and Anna will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the transition from paper car tax discs to an electronic system, announced by Chancellor George Osborne in his Autumn Statement. Stephen Hammond, the minister, responded to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges' concerns about job losses among DVLA employees. Hammond assured that while job roles may change due to reduced refunds and the need for training on new processes, the DVLA would manage any necessary reductions by redeploying staff to other growing areas of the business. This response was welcomed by Hedges, who acknowledged the advantages of the new system despite the reduction in job opportunities. The minister's commitment to redeployment rather than redundancies provided comfort to concerned employees.

The passage discusses Hungary's stance on EU interference in its domestic policies, particularly regarding asylum controls, restrictions on NGOs, and a higher education law that has sparked controversy. Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, has passed two of these laws and plans to pass a third targeting NGOs. The EU disapproves of these measures, especially the education law which could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University (CEU), founded by philanthropist George Soros. Hungary has received support from Poland, which has stated it will veto any EU attempt to sanction Hungary. The Hungarian government is defiant, stating there is no reason to backtrack on the laws, as they fall under national competence. EU rules require unanimous approval for sanctions, and Hungary's actions are causing tension within the EU. The EU has raised concerns about Hungary's treatment of asylum seekers, housing them in shipping containers, which may not be compatible with EU law. The NGO law is expected to be debated in parliament soon and is criticized by human rights groups for potentially stigmatizing NGOs as "foreign-backed." The EU's Deputy Commission head, Frans Timmermans, has warned of action if there are no positive developments.

The 2017 live-action adaptation of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" features Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Belle's father, Maurice, and Harry Potter star Emma Watson was cast as Belle in January. Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in Frozen, will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Bill Condon, director of Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films, will direct the film, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The passage describes the death of Adrian Gill, a columnist for The Sunday Times, who passed away after battling "the full English" of cancers. Gill was known for his controversial and witty writing style, often causing outrage with his candid and provocative comments on various topics, including animal rights, regional stereotypes, and public figures. Despite his illness, he maintained a positive outlook and continued to write until his death. His final column, about coming to terms with his diagnosis, was published in tomorrow's Sunday Times. Gill was highly regarded by his peers, with former editors and colleagues praising his unique writing style, intelligence, and kindness. He was married twice and had four children. His death has left a profound impact on his workplace and the wider journalism community.

The passage describes an incident involving Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, who was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator. According to Russian news reports, he was hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face. The rapper was wearing a red deel adorned with a swastika, which is a traditional Mongolian symbol that predates the Nazi association. Sukhbaatar's father stated that his son was in a coma for about 10 days after the attack due to serious injuries. The Russian embassy confirmed they were investigating the incident, citing discrepancies in local press reports. The swastika used by Sukhbaatar is not a hate symbol in Mongolia but is used by some far-right groups there as well. The rapper's lawyer emphasized that Sukhbaatar did not shout "Heil Hitler" during the performance. The suspect in the attack is a Russian diplomatic officer, and despite being a diplomat, he was not exempt from investigation due to the severity of the alleged crime. The police are investigating the case, and the suspect is expected to be held accountable under Mongolian law.

Plane Stupid campaigners staged a protest on the northern runway of Heathrow Airport at 03:30 BST on Monday. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. The protesters will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police will review airport security following the protest.
