The passage describes the arrest of Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, by North Wales Police in August. Hughes was arrested after he engaged in online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, during which he made threats to murder police officers. Specifically, he planned to report a non-existent crime to lure police to the Dee Estuary, where he intended to shoot them. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and will be sentenced next week. His threats were made while he was intoxicated late at night. The court heard that Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. His legal team stated that Hughes did not intend to kill himself and would not have carried out the threat to kill police officers. The Hope Line Crisis Centre provides confidential support and counseling to individuals experiencing difficulty. North Wales Police was particularly concerned because Hughes was on bail at the time, awaiting trial for firearms offenses, which he was later cleared of.

The passage describes a cricket match where Yorkshire was chasing a target of 237 set by Surrey. Yorkshire was reduced to 8-2 early on but then put up a substantial score of 255-7, with a key partnership of 130 between Davies and Ben Foakes. The match was turned by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who dismissed Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan made 68 but Yorkshire fell short, finishing all out for 236. Surrey won the match, and their captain, Gareth Batty, praised his team's performance, particularly the partnership of Davies and Foakes, which he felt should have been even larger. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, acknowledging that they had not been good enough in crucial moments and that their chase was undermined by a lack of contribution from the top of the order.

The passage describes an incident involving a 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler that was 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack. At 07:00 BST, the crew of the boat contacted coastguards to report that their onboard pump was unable to handle the amount of water entering the vessel. In response, the Holyhead coastguards were alerted to the situation. The Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) dispatched their lifeboat to assist. The lifeboat crew took action by providing a pump to the stricken vessel and then towing it to the safety of Holyhead. This summary covers the key points: the location of the incident, the boat's condition, the crew's call for help, the involvement of coastguards, and the lifeboat's intervention to save the boat and its crew.

The passage discusses Scottish middle distance runner Laura Muir's decision not to compete at the 2022 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir, who is 24 years old, finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships. Her exams are scheduled for May, and since the Commonwealth Games are in April, she won't be able to attend. Muir is disappointed about missing the opportunity to run for Scotland but prioritizes her education. She believes her team will perform well at the Commonwealth Games and expresses confidence in her potential for future Olympic appearances. She mentions the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target for her next competition. Despite her busy schedule with studies, she is in good shape and hopes to compete in the World Championships in Birmingham.

The loss of Luis Suarez and the limited contributions from Rickie Lambert and Mario Balotelli are highlighted.

3. **Work-Rate and Intensity**: The passage notes that Liverpool's intensity and work-rate have decreased compared to last season, which is reflected in their scoring rate and pressing style.

4. **Defensive Weakness**: Despite Rodgers spending money on defenders, the defense remains a problem, with Liverpool statistically no better than last season but also no worse.

5. **Set-Piece Decline**: Liverpool's reliance on set-pieces has diminished, with fewer goals coming from corners and free-kicks.

The £45m facility in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The East Ayrshire Council plans to ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus after the renowned writer, William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. William McIlvanney was an English teacher who later became a full-time writer. He gained recognition with his first novel, "Remedy Is None," and was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" due to his works like the Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based novels. McIlvanney was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and made significant contributions to political and sporting life in Scotland through his columns and TV programs. He passed away at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

The passage describes an evacuation and safety precautions taken due to the discovery of a sea mine near a swimming pool in a town. The mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted on Monday and prompted the evacuation of three streets and an exclusion zone on the river. Residents within 500 meters of the device were advised to stay indoors and keep windows open. An exclusion zone at sea, about half a mile wide, prevented small boat owners from sailing. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, with no immediate danger to the community. Experts were moving the deteriorated mine to a safer location for disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and safe evacuation procedures.

The passage discusses funding cuts for several sports by UK Sport, which allocates money to support Olympic and Paralympic medal potential. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have had their funding cut. Cycling, which brought Team GB 12 medals in Rio, has seen its funding reduced from £40.98m to £25.98m. Badminton England's CEO is "staggered" by the decision to remove badminton's funding despite the sport achieving a bronze medal in Rio. The total funding for Olympic and Paralympic sports is £345m, £2m less than the Rio Games allocation. UK Sport has set a target for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The decision to cut funding was not taken lightly, with UK Sport prioritizing to protect and enhance medal potential. Basketball, handball, and volleyball had their funding withdrawn in previous cycles, expressing disappointment that UK Sport refuses to fund their performance development despite a review suggesting otherwise. Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area are set to be demolished to make way for a new six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage opposed the development due to its scale, but the planning board voted in favor, citing the need to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older people in the town. The buildings—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and The Ocean View hotels—are considered no longer "functional" and are to be replaced by a 90-room hotel and two apartment blocks with 122 assisted-living units. The East Cliff Project LLP is behind the development, which has received support from 246 letter writers but objections from 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society, who argue that the hotels, despite alterations, contribute to the historic character of the area. The council's decision was influenced by the need for progress and the potential benefits to tourism, despite the regrettable loss of buildings and trees.

The passage describes the tragic death of Pte Matthew Boyd, a soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, who was killed in Brecon, Wales, after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely during an off-duty night out. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar as Pte Boyd was making his way back to the barracks. Vallely, who was on a seven-hour drinking binge and claimed to be the "hardest man in Brecon," dragged Pte Boyd's unconscious body from the scene and fled.

Aaeron Evans, a friend of Vallely, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8. The death shocked the community of Brecon and prompted a plea from the investigating officer, Det Supt David Guiney, for people to avoid violence when drinking.

Pte Boyd was described as an "all-rounder" with a promising career ahead of him, who was loving, caring, and loyal. His family expressed their unbearable pain and described Vallely's actions as creating a void that will never be filled. They also noted the community's support as the strongest people in Brecon, contradicting Vallely

The summary of the passage is as follows: Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement after an error resulted in voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched by the council. Travers stated that he enjoyed his time at Barnet and believes the council's changes will enable the borough to thrive. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while longer-term arrangements are made. On election day, staff at one polling station reported that only three of the first 30 voters were registered. The council apologised for the problems and later offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. Residents questioned the fairness of the election due to the inability of many to vote. Travers blamed the issue on electoral registration lists. The council's review is expected to conclude by the end of May and the findings will be presented to the General Functions Committee. Discussions are ongoing to determine who will lead the investigation into the EU Referendum arrangements.

The match between Gateshead and Wrexham ended with Gateshead winning 2-1. Gateshead took the lead with a fine free-kick by Josh Gillies, but Wrexham equalized with a set-piece goal by Sean Newton before halftime. In the second half, Gateshead secured the victory with a header from a cross by Craig Baxter, scored by Ryan Bowman. Gateshead's manager praised his team's performance in the second half, while Wrexham's manager acknowledged their second-half performance was not as strong as the first. Gateshead's second goal was described as a "great bit of play" with a "wonderful cross" and a "great finish."

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic well-being of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is ranked the best, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are at the bottom of the list.

The OneWeb project aims to launch a constellation of over 2,000 broadband satellites to provide global internet coverage, starting with at least 600 spacecraft. Airbus, Europe's largest space company, is involved in manufacturing these satellites, which require a shift towards high-volume, low-cost production methods akin to those used in car and plane manufacturing. This involves new assembly line techniques and the use of trolley robots to move satellites between workstations. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April 2019, with more following in November. The constellation will be established through a record-breaking rocket campaign using Soyuz rockets to launch clusters of satellites. Airbus and OneWeb believe they have a first-mover advantage over competitors. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is in discussions to secure the necessary loans. The UK Space Agency will be involved as the licensing authority due to OneWeb's UK company registration. The project is committed to debris mitigation, aiming to de-orbit satellites within two years to prevent space from becoming unusable due to debris. Airbus and OneWeb hope to set new standards in satellite manufacturing and potentially offer their assembly line services to other companies. However, not all satellites will require such high

The passage discusses the financial pressures on Scotland's public expenditure due to the UK government's spending review. The UK government announced that Scottish ministers would have £390 million more in spending available next year. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 have led to a 12.5% reduction in discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. The Scottish Finance Secretary, John Swinney, stated that George Osborne's austerity measures will result in over £1 billion in cuts by the end of the decade. Swinney emphasized that despite these cuts, the Scottish government will prioritize key areas like schools, hospitals, and the police service. He also criticized the UK government's approach to reducing debt and deficit, claiming it could have been done without such severe cuts. The UK government's Scotland Office responded by highlighting the increased funding available to Scotland and the stability of the UK economy. They suggested that the Scottish government should focus on preparing for the new powers coming with devolution rather than focusing on grievances. Labour's Jackie Baillie called for a long-term budget from the Scottish government, advocating for a different approach to taxation and public spending to offer an alternative to austerity.

The passage discusses the lack of suitable toilet facilities for individuals with severe disabilities and their families, highlighting the need for "Changing Places" toilets. These toilets are larger and equipped with features such as a changing bench and hoist, essential for people who require assistance to use the toilet. The current situation leaves many families feeling isolated and stressed about managing their loved ones' needs when they go out. Lorna Fillingham, a mother of a six-year-old with disabilities, started a petition to make the installation of Changing Places toilets compulsory in new larger buildings, such as shopping centres, cinemas, and sports stadiums. The lack of such facilities can lead to feelings of exclusion and guilt among parents. The passage also mentions that there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but many more are needed. It includes testimonials from families who have experienced the difficulties of managing changes in public places and the relief they feel when Changing Places facilities are available. The passage concludes by noting that while some businesses have taken steps to install Changing Places toilets, it is recommended that building regulations make their installation compulsory in larger new buildings to ensure accessibility for all.

A formal complaint has been lodged with the European Commission by Italian consumer groups, alleging that McDonald's forces franchisees to pay exorbitant rents and fees. McDonald's responded by stating their commitment to sharing risks and rewards with franchisees, which they claim has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and various European unions are backing the complaint, arguing that McDonald's abuse of its dominant market position negatively impacts franchisees, consumers, and workers. They are urging the European Commission to investigate the claims and hold McDonald's accountable. The consumer organizations also claim that franchisees are restricted from switching to competitors due to long-term contracts and are forced to lease premises from McDonald's at above-market rates, which they say leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned locations. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe. McDonald's generated $9.27 billion in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

The poster with the hashtag #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood by the A2 within the last week. It is part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down. Joshua was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve and was supposed to have an operation on his appendix at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, but doctors discovered and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths instead. The news shocked Josh's family, but they have received lots of support from people all over the world, starting as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Joshua's father is on the pastoral staff. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, was amazed by the support and said they just wanted people to pray for Josh. The hashtag went viral, with over 79,000 views on a post about Josh. A mystery donor paid for a massive billboard at Holywood playing fields. Josh's classmates are also using the hashtag on Twitter to show their support. The campaign started as a local effort but has now spread globally, thanks to the kindness of strangers in County Down.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic military installation in Brecon, Wales, which has been home to troops since 1805 and has a history of service in conflicts dating back to the early 19th century. The decision to close the barracks has been condemned by Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies, who describes it as "abhorrent" and plans to fight against it. He raises concerns about the lack of respect shown towards the barracks' history and the potential impact on the local community, particularly in light of high unemployment levels in the area.

Mr. Davies also mentions the launch of a petition against the closure and hopes it will not harm Brecon's thriving military tourism industry. Despite the closure, he reassures that civilian staff and military personnel positions are not at risk, and the nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines will remain unaffected.

The defense secretary, Sir Michael Fallon, announced the reorganization of military buildings and the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, as part of the restructuring. The closure of Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire and a storage depot at Senny

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry, particularly regarding access to UK waters for EU-registered boats and the future of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). It highlights that fishing regions in the UK voted heavily to leave the EU during the referendum campaign, driven in part by dissatisfaction with the CFP, which they view as a disaster for British fishing.

The Lords review points out that these communities might be marginalized in the broader Brexit negotiations, despite the industry's potential to regain control over UK waters and become a leading exporter of fish, similar to Norway. The report emphasizes that while the UK fishing industry contributes minimally to GDP and employs a small workforce, it should not be overlooked in the negotiations.

A key complication is that many commercially valuable fish stocks are shared between the UK and other EU coastal states. The report suggests that a successful industry post-Brexit will require continued market access to the EU, which might come with the condition of granting more access to UK waters to EU boats.

The Lords committee recommends retaining elements of the CFP, such as basing quotas on scientific advice, and warns that Brexit could lead to four different fisheries management regimes across the UK. However, industry representatives

Ed Snowden, a 29-year-old former technical worker for the CIA, leaked documents revealing the NSA's access to massive amounts of individual data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. Prism, a tool mentioned in the leaked documents, allegedly provided "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major technology companies, enabling the NSA to access vast amounts of user data. The leaked information showed that the US government requested millions of phone records from Verizon, which included call duration, location, and phone numbers. Prism also allowed access to private posts on social media, web chats, and internet searches. Companies named in the leaks, such as Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and others, have denied their involvement, and the exact workings of Prism remain unclear. The US government argues that such surveillance is necessary for national security, with President Obama stating that preventing terrorism overrules privacy concerns. Different countries have varying data protection laws, but they generally regulate what companies can do with customer data rather than government activity. The US Patriot Act and FISA Act allow American authorities to access European data stored in the US, raising concerns about privacy. The extent of other governments' involvement in Prism is unclear,

The venture OpenAI is backed by notable figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Its goal is to conduct AI research focused on positive human impact, without financial constraints. Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking have expressed concerns about AI's potential to threaten humanity, with Musk stating it's the biggest existential threat and Hawking warning about AI outpacing biological evolution. However, other experts believe the risk of AI harming humans is currently remote. OpenAI aims to distribute AI technology as widely and evenly as possible, safely, to benefit society. The venture has received $1 billion in funding, with only a small portion allocated for the upcoming years.

The passage describes Ben Parkinson, a British soldier who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite his injuries, which included a brain injury that affected his speech, Parkinson has become a symbol of resilience and determination. After carrying the Olympic torch in Doncaster on June 26, he received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, which is limited to 5,000 per personal page. Despite this limitation, he has inspired a significant amount of support and interest, with his mother, Diane, noting the "phenomenal" response and the increased mail and email traffic.

Parkinson spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, walking with crutches, and dedicates his remaining time to fundraising for military charities and supporting his beloved Pilgrim Bandits. His nomination for carrying the torch highlighted his unchanged personality, sense of humor, and determination to prove everyone wrong about his capabilities following his injuries.

The passage also mentions that a total of 8,000 people will carry the Olympic torch during its journey to the opening ceremony of the London 2012 Olympic Games on July 27.

The poverty rate in 2011 was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty, marking a flat rate after three years of increases. The real median income of households dropped by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four in 2011 was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% in 2011, the first annual rise since 1993. In 2010, poverty in the US reached a record high at 15.1%. In 2011, the percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%.

The passage describes the transfer and contract extension of Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, from Somerset to Lancashire in 2013. Buttler is known for his prowess in limited-over formats, particularly his ability to score ODI centuries quickly. He holds the record for the third fastest ODI century, achieved in 46 balls against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praises Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers in the game, citing his contribution to Lancashire's T20 Blast final victory and his positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler has been playing in the Indian Premier League with the Mumbai Indians and will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until January 23 to register interest in the ships, but no proposals to preserve them have been submitted. Those who have shown interest are finalizing their bids and will have viewings in late February and March. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, a Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, believes it's important for UK recyclers to prove themselves but also wants to see at least one ship saved from the scrapyard. She suggests turning one into a reef and diving attraction, which could generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer. The frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with various weapon systems. They had a complement of about 280 crew and were known for their excellent command and control facilities, making them ideal flagships on deployments. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m.

The passage describes the history of racial and political instability in Fiji, starting with a coup in 1987 that overthrew an Indian-dominated government and led to a series of adverse events, including constitutional changes and economic harm. The 2000 coup resulted in the kidnapping of the prime minister and his cabinet, further damaging the economy and international reputation. Tensions persisted over amnesty for the coup leaders, culminating in a bloodless military takeover in 2006, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years. In 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth due to its lack of progress towards democracy. Following an agreement to hold free elections in 2014, diplomatic ties were restored with Australia and New Zealand. The population of Fiji is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter group having decreased due to emigration following coups. The country has experienced economic challenges, including trade and budget deficits, making it a large recipient of aid. Fiji's economy is diverse, relying on sugar, tourism, mining, and a strong services sector, but it has been hindered by these economic issues.

The passage discusses Syria's compliance with the destruction of its chemical weapons stockpile, which was supposed to be completed by the end of June. Syria missed a Wednesday deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. The deputy foreign minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, explained that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia. He stated that two shipments had been sent to the Syrian coast, with the second one being intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. Al-Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry for condemning the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which reportedly killed 246 people, including 73 children, in the last five days. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and Aleppo Media Centre reported attacks by barrel bombs on civilians in Aleppo. Al-Mekdad insisted that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks and denied bombing civilian areas. He accused the US of still supporting terrorist elements in Syria. The passage also mentions that rebels had seized Aleppo's central prison, despite the Syrian government's claim that soldiers thwarted the attack. The Lives of Others by Jhumpa Mukherjee is the favorite to win the Booker Prize, with William Hill listing it as a 5/2 favorite. The prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality, marking the first year of this change. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlist includes Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan, with Jacobson being the favorite at 5/2. Mukherjee's The Lives of Others begins in Calcutta in 1967 and focuses on secrets and rivalries within a family against a backdrop of political activism. Smith's How To Be Both tells two interlinking stories, one about a renaissance artist in 15th Century Italy and the other about a child of the 1960s. Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour explores atheism through the eyes of a New York dentist. Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is the best-selling novel on the shortlist, having sold over 55,000 copies since its publication in March. The announcement of the shortlist caused a sales spike for all

The passage describes a legal battle involving a man, referred to as PJS, who is a celebrity with young children and a spouse also in the public eye. He has taken legal action against The Sun on Sunday, which wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities involving PJS. The Court of Appeal initially ruled in his favor, banning the publication of his name in England and Wales and allowing an interim injunction to remain in place until the hearing's conclusion. The Sun on Sunday challenged this ban, arguing that the story had already been published in other countries and on the internet, making confidentiality impossible. The Court of Appeal then lifted the ban, stating that the details had become too widespread to maintain confidentiality. PJS opposed this decision and sought to keep the ban in place. The Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal against the Court of Appeal's decision, with the possibility of deciding whether to allow or dismiss the appeal. Meanwhile, the interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased in August 1989 for £345.5 million. The new owners, Crown Estates, are planning to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units at the site. The Blaby District Council leader, Ernie White, mentioned that the council met with the new owners to address potential planning issues. Fosse Park serves as the gateway from Blaby into the city, and the owners view it as an investment for improvement. Currently, the view upon entering the city is dominated by the backs of sheds. The directors of investments at Crown Estates are particularly concerned with addressing parking and congestion issues, as well as the quality of the common areas and facilities at Fosse Park to ensure it is as good as it can be.

The film "Beauty and the Beast," a live-action remake, sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving a character named LeFou. Disney decided to hold the film for a review of its content in Malaysia, where homosexual activity is illegal in Muslim-majority countries. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit to the "gay moment," allowing it to be screened. The film was initially set to be released on Thursday but a new release date has not yet been announced. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification." The decision to review the film in Malaysia was criticized by netizens, who called it "stupid and laughable." The controversy led local cinema chains to offer refunds for advance tickets.

The passage discusses the requirement for landlords in Southampton, UK, to obtain a licence for Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) when renting to more than three unrelated people. The cost of the licence is a deterrent for some landlords, despite the potential fine of up to £20,000 for not having a licence. Southampton City Council estimated there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants of HMOs often express concerns about eviction and living in poorly maintained properties due to the lack of regulation. The shortage of affordable homes forces people into these unregulated rental situations, leading to frequent calls to Shelter's helpline. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to HMOs with three or more storeys and five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, the licensing applies to specific areas and designations, with the council having taken legal action against one firm and 13 individuals for not obtaining the necessary licences.

The passage discusses the political situation in Ireland following the recent election. Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are trying to avoid a second election by forming a minority government. The main obstacle to an agreement is the issue of water charges. A proposal being considered is the establishment of a commission to examine the future of Irish Water, the national water utility. Fianna Fáil wants to abolish water charges immediately, while Fine Gael believes water charges have a role to play. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil had 44, Sinn Féin had 23, and the Labour Party had 7. No party was able to form a majority government, and so far, TDs have not been able to elect a Taoiseach.

The passage describes an incident involving the Italian ferry, The Sorrento, which caught fire while en route to Valencia. The fire started on one of the car decks about 27km from Mallorca. Passengers were evacuated using lifeboats and rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured and taken to hospital by helicopter. The injured include one person who is seriously hurt. The ship was about 17 miles from Mallorca when the fire started on Tuesday afternoon. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were dispatched to assist. The passengers and crew were transferred to life rafts and eventually boarded a rescue ferry, the Puglia. They are on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and are expected to arrive at the port in a few hours. Spanish officials stated that due to the severity of the fire, The Sorrento may sink. The ferry is owned by the Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione. The distress signals were sent at 11:50 GMT. Initially, the captain did not believe an evacuation was necessary, but the fire became too intense, leading to a full evacuation.

The passage discusses the issue of duplicate voter registrations, which some individuals, including students, allegedly used to vote twice in the 2017 general election. The Electoral Commission highlighted that 38 MPs reported cases of people claiming to have voted twice, which is illegal. The problem stems from the fact that electoral registers managed by local councils are not well-integrated with the online registration service, leading to a significant number of duplicate applications. Between December 2016 and May 2017, 4.9 million applications were submitted online, but the increase in the electoral register was only 1.4 million, suggesting that 30-70% of these applications were duplicates. This has caused administrative burdens and financial costs for electoral officials. The lack of a direct link between the online registration service and the local council databases means there is no easy way for individuals to check if they are already registered, leading to further duplication. The Electoral Commission suggests improving information on registration sites and potentially implementing a verification function, similar to systems used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. While there is no concrete evidence of people voting twice in the general election, the issue is taken seriously, and the police are urged to prosecute those suspected of double voting.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star player at the University of Nebraska and NFL player for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, died by suicide early on Wednesday. In the 1990s, he was a sought-after rookie due to his talent on the field. However, Phillips struggled with both legal and personal issues throughout his life. His NFL career was marked by trouble, including driving his car into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend, which led to his imprisonment for over 30 years. While in prison, he was accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, for which there was enough evidence to proceed to trial. Phillips was serving a lengthy sentence when he died. His former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as an intelligent person with good qualities but also noted that Phillips struggled with anger issues and was unable to overcome the demons in his life.

The passage describes the promotion of Private Derby XXX, a ram, to the rank of lance corporal at an event in Chester to mark eight years of the Mercian Regiment. The promotion was awarded for "good behaviour," making him the 30th in a lineage of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. The first Private Derby was acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858 and became the mascot of the Mercian Regiment when it formed in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014 and has his own army number, receives payment for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Throughout his career, he has participated in community events such as switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

The passage describes a thrilling UEFA Europa League match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund at Anfield on Thursday, 19 March 2021. Liverpool, managed by Jurgen Klopp, secured a 4-3 victory over Dortmund, a team managed by Thomas Tuchel. The match was characterized by intense emotions, drama, and brilliant football, with both teams scoring three goals each.

Key points from the passage include:

1. **The Match Outcome**: Liverpool won 4-3 in extra time, with Dejan Lovren scoring the decisive goal.

2. **Managerial Influence**: Klopp's intense and inspirational touchline behavior was pivotal in turning the game around. He invoked the spirit of past Liverpool triumphs, particularly the 2005 Champions League Final, to motivate his team.

3. **Dramatic Turnaround**: Liverpool was down 2-0 early but fought back to equalize and then score three more goals, showcasing resilience and belief.

4. **Atmosphere and Support**: The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with a powerful rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone" and a minute's silence for the Hillsborough disaster victims.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, where David Davis, the UK Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, stated that the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations. However, Kenny MacAskill, the Scottish Minister for International Relations and Europe, emphasized the need for transparency regarding the UK government's plans. Davis proposed monthly meetings to share analysis and create a "two-way information flow" with the devolved administrations. He aimed to involve these governments in shaping the negotiating strategy for the UK's exit from the EU. Despite the UK government's efforts to engage, MacAskill pointed out the lack of clarity on the UK's intentions regarding EU market access, particularly the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economic prosperity. The Scottish government plans to challenge the UK government's approach in the Supreme Court, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe intending to oppose the UK government's stance during the appeal of the High Court's Article 50 decision.

The passage describes a veterinary surgeon, Dr. Sandra Corr, examining Daisy, a cloned sheep, for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is part of a flock of 13 cloned sheep, four of which (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) are clones of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. These sheep are being closely monitored to study aging and health in cloned animals. The concern is whether cloned animals age normally or if they might age prematurely due to the cloning process. The passage mentions that Dolly, the original sheep from which Daisy and the other clones were created, died at six and a half years old from a virus, but also suffered from osteoarthritis, raising questions about premature aging in cloned animals. The study involves regular health assessments, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, to monitor the health of the cloned sheep and compare them to the wider population of sheep. The results of this study could have significant implications for the future of cloning.

The passage discusses several horse races and the performances of specific horses. Here is a concise summary:

- Gosden is pleased to have a month to prepare Shutter Speed for the Chant

The currency initially fell against the dollar and euro but recovered in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. The "volatility index" reached levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign claimed the pound had only retreated to March levels, with the pound down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226 and down 0.6% against the euro at â‚¬1.2605. Investors' uncertainty has increased due to polls showing a closer race between the Leave and Remain camps, and global economic worries. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group leading the fallers. The Leave campaign highlighted that the pound had strengthened since the possibility of Brexit became apparent, which they argued was beneficial for UK exporters.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They lost to Barrow after conceding a goal early on, despite having traveled for a long time. The defeat extended Braintree's losing streak to three games, but their manager, Cowley, remained positive. He stated that their performance so far has been remarkable, but the journey ahead will not be easy. Braintree are a part-time team facing their toughest challenge yet in the National League. Cowley encourages his team to embrace the challenge and see where it leads them.

The passage discusses a significant change in the planning system in Northern Ireland, where from April 2015, local councils will take over the responsibility for planning decisions from the Planning Service, which is part of Stormont's environment department. This shift aims to democratize the planning system by allowing elected politicians to make these decisions, which Michael Corr, a creative director of PLACE, views as a positive move offering local councils the chance to develop their own community and development plans.

However, there are concerns about whether politicians have the necessary skills to handle planning decisions effectively. There is a historical context to these concerns, as local councils in Northern Ireland were accused of discrimination in the allocation of public housing in the 1960s, which contributed to the Civil Rights movement.

Friends of the Earth express worry that without a strict code of conduct, the new councils might handle planning matters unfairly, leading to a repeat of past injustices. They also point out the potential for conflicts of interest due to the close relationships between developers and political parties, which could result in a "laissez-faire" system where proper democratic planning is neglected.

The passage also touches on the transparency of political donations, which becomes more critical as politicians gain

The passage describes an incident where a one-year-old cat named Teenie was found with two gunshot wounds in her shoulder and one in her back leg, which required the amputation of her leg. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found Teenie on a housing estate in NiddryView, Winchburgh, on Friday, 14 March, at around 16:30. The gun used was powerful enough to pass through the cat's leg, causing severe damage that necessitated amputation. Teenie is now learning to walk again, hopping around her house. Mrs. Nisbett expresses concern about the safety of children in the area who could have been hit by stray bullets. The Scottish SPCA is seeking information about the incident to identify and prosecute the person responsible. The passage also mentions a previous consultation by the Scottish government on licensing air weapons, which was opposed by a majority of respondents. The proposed licensing scheme would require individuals to demonstrate a legitimate reason for owning an air gun and would aid police in tracing irresponsible users. Despite a large majority of respondents opposing the licensing plan, the Scottish SPCA still advocates for its implementation to prevent such incidents.

The passage describes the transfer of Belgian forward Divock Benteke from Aston Villa to Liverpool. Benteke, 24, becomes Liverpool's second most expensive signing, following the £49m sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. He has signed a long-term contract with the club, who are aiming to strengthen their attack after finishing sixth in the Premier League last season with a lack of goals. Benteke has a history of scoring consistently, having netted 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since joining from Genk in 2012. He has expressed his excitement about joining Liverpool, aiming to help the team win trophies and achieve great goals together. The passage also mentions other signings by Liverpool, including forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and the return of Divock Origi, all aimed at bolstering the team's attacking options. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October, scoring 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former managers, including Paul Lambert and Roberto Martinez, have praised Benteke's abilities and potential impact at Liverpool. Former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is optimistic about

The passage discusses the integration of tablet computers in schools and their impact on student learning and engagement. Key points include:

1. **Prevalence of Tablets in Schools**: Tablets are now used in 68% of primary schools and 69% of secondary schools, with academy schools showing the highest use.

2. **Individual Tablet Devices**: In 9% of schools, there is an individual tablet for every pupil.

3. **Rapid Growth**: The number of tablet computers in schools is expected to increase from about 430,000 in 2014 to almost 900,000 by 2016.

4. **Head Teachers' Perspective**: Despite no definitive connection between tablet computers and improved results, head teachers reported a positive impact, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and involving families.

5. **Family and Home Use**: Many pupils take a tablet device to bed to continue social media conversations, and children in poorer households are particularly likely to read on touch-screen computers rather than printed books.

6. **Internet Addiction and Usage**: A quarter of secondary pupils described themselves as internet "addicts," and about two-thirds take a computer device or smartphone to bed.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 evocative photographs capturing the life of children over more than 100 years. The images provide a snapshot of childhood experiences and a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool. The photographs range from the 1880s to the 1990s and illustrate how much life for a child has changed, as well as how special occasions were marked on the city's streets. The oldest image dates back to 1887 and depicts the Rollo family from Waterloo Park, dressed up for a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle. Another image shows a young maid from a well-to-do Liverpool family, captured around 1900, indicating that many children were also sent out to work. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool, who selected 25 images from hundreds in the museum's collections. The exhibition runs until September 25 and aims to showcase both the joyful and challenging aspects of childhood experiences.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals. He has experience with Aldershot, Exeter, and played in Italy. He could play against his former club, Aldershot, on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, is moving to Exeter from Port Vale. Micky Adams, ex-Port Vale manager, recommended him to Exeter boss Kevin Nicholson. Keating has had spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Nicholson describes him as a leader with the qualities he has been seeking. The move is subject to international clearance. Exeter is currently four points above the relegation zone in the league and has won only one of their last six games.

The new legislation in Bolivia allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs as one of the poorest in South America. It introduces harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year prison sentence for child homicide. The law was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia in the absence of President Evo Morales, who was in Brazil. More than 500,000 children in Bolivia already work to supplement family income, with many working in harsh conditions in mines and agriculture fields. The Morales government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries but sets 15 as the minimum globally. The ILO is studying the Bolivian law to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

The passage describes the experience of actress and writer Jane O'Donnell, who at the age of 50, suffered a heart attack known as the "widow maker." This type of heart attack is particularly severe and occurs when an artery is 99% blocked. O'Donnell initially ignored her symptoms, which included sudden nausea, chest ache, and fever, after helping a woman at her Nyack village home near New York. She only sought medical attention the next day, when she visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent to open the blocked artery.

O'Donnell wrote about her experience on her blog, sharing a poem titled "my heart attack," and emphasized the importance of recognizing the symptoms of a heart attack, especially in women, who often experience different signs than men. She did not call emergency services herself but urges her readers to do so if they suspect they or someone else is having a heart attack.

The passage also mentions O'Donnell's career, including her roles in films and TV shows like "Drop Dead Diva," "Will and Grace," and "Nip/Tuck," and her brief stint hosting "The Rosie Show" on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was cancelled

The passage describes an incident where a boy named Che Labastide-Wellington, aged 16, from Harrow, was stabbed to death during a party in Kenton, London, on Saturday night. The stabbing occurred after a fight with a group of youths who tried to enter the party. Che was later involved in a scuffle in an alleyway at around 00:30 GMT and was pronounced dead an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital for treatment, where he is in a stable condition. The party was described as "a well-run event with appropriate adults in attendance," and Che was not involved in an early altercation with the youths denied entry. However, he was later targeted. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder and is being questioned at a west London police station. Two boys aged 15 and 16 have also been arrested on suspicion of murder and have been bailed until mid-December. Additionally, a third boy, aged 14, is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes a reorganization in Denmark's approach to cancer diagnosis following poor survival statistics. The issue was long waiting times for diagnosis, particularly for less obvious cancer cases. The solution implemented was a three-route model:

1. **Fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes** for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers, with strict time targets.
2. **Diagnosis centres** were established to quickly test and scan patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose, ensuring a prompt diagnosis whether the result is cancer or not.
3. **"Yes-no" centres** for patients with minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer but where there's a small chance of a serious disease. These centres offer simple tests or scans to quickly identify any problems.

These changes were designed to reduce waiting times and improve cancer survival rates. The system has not overwhelmed the healthcare system but has improved the organization of patient diagnosis within existing resources. As a result, Denmark has seen better survival rates compared to before, and the country is catching up with other European leaders in cancer care. The passage suggests that Wales could learn from Denmark's approach to improve its own cancer diagnosis and treatment processes.

The passage describes a change in the regulatory framework for estate agents in the UK. The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) is being disbanded, and its functions are being taken over by a new body, Powys County Council, which has won a competitive bidding process to deliver this service. This new body will be able to issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. The local authorities will still handle complaints about estate agents, but they will refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to carry out this work. The aim is for Powys to demonstrate its capability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future. James Munro, who will lead the new team, has expressed hope that this new role will open up opportunities for Powys in terms of additional contracts and external work.

The passage discusses a proposal by NHS Employers to expand the roles of non-doctor healthcare professionals, such as nurses and pharmacists, to fill gaps in the NHS workforce. This is in response to documented shortages in junior doctor rosters and GP services, exacerbated by a rising patient load. The Nuffield Trust reviewed the situation and found instances where nurses were filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The report suggests that this is not only necessary due to current staffing shortages but also aligns with the changing nature of healthcare, which increasingly focuses on managing chronic conditions rather than curing them. The report highlights examples of successful experiments in workforce reshaping, emphasizing the potential for nurses to play a more significant role in patient care. However, there are concerns raised by unions and the British Medical Association about the quality of training for doctors and the potential for this initiative to undermine doctor expertise. The NHS Employers chief executive Danny Mortimer acknowledges the challenge ahead in implementing the report's recommendations. The article concludes with calls for careful consideration of how to fund and manage this workforce reshaping without compromising the quality of training and care.

The passage describes a road closure due to a crash on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road was closed, causing disruption and delays for commuters and bus services during rush hour. The closure lasted until 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First, the company operating the bus services, stated that while some services had returned to normal, it would take a few hours for all services to resume their regular schedule. Managing director James Freeman expressed gratitude for the public's support and understanding, as well as thanks to the staff who went beyond their duties to manage the situation and recovery efforts.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the estimated impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on local fish populations, particularly salmon and sea trout. The North Wales Wildlife Site (NRW) estimated that the lagoon would result in a 21% annual mortality rate for salmon and a 25% rate for sea trout due to the obstruction of their migration routes. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the company behind the project, disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and accusing the regulator of refusing to share their methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of only 2% of all fish species being affected. The Swansea tidal lagoon project is seen as a pilot for larger, more cost-effective projects along the UK coast. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, and while Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths supports the scheme, she calls for clarity on the UK government's stance. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and stands by their methodology, which they claim is based on the best available evidence and has been reviewed by independent experts. The decision on the project's environmental impact is pending further review.

The passage discusses the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland. This body is intended to be similar to the already successful Scotland Food and Drink marketing body. The announcement was made by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster. She emphasized the importance of Northern Ireland's agri-food industry, which includes farming, fishing, retail, and distribution, and employs nearly 100,000 people. The development of this marketing body is part of the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB)'s responsibilities. The Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, highlighting agri-food as a key sector for export-led economic growth in Northern Ireland. She acknowledged the need for better coordination of marketing activities within the industry. However, she also noted that the creation of this new body could have implications for the work of other organizations, including her own department. The minister expressed a willingness to discuss the plans with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is planting 40,000 native trees in Brackfield Wood, located in the Faughan Valley, as part of a four-year project to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. This initiative is one of the trust's most ambitious planting programs, using the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." The trees are being planted to honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The public is invited to participate in the tree planting, making a personal contribution to the wood and marking history. The Woodland Trust provides saplings for volunteers to plant, and participants are advised to wear welly boots or sturdy footwear. The completed wood will be a habitat for wildlife and a place for reflection, with carpets of wildflowers including poppies. Brackfield Wood is situated seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available for participants. The trees will serve as a living tribute to the soldiers, their families, and loved ones from Ireland who were involved in the war.

Hilary's novel, "Someone Else's Skin," won Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the Harrogate Crime Writing Festival. The book, which features Det Insp Marnie Rome and deals with domestic violence and "honour crime," was praised for its atmosphere and subject matter. Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, noted the book's "finely written and tightly written" nature and its ability to "conjure up atmosphere in very few lines." Sara Paretsky, the creator of detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI, a groundbreaking female private investigator. Paretsky's work was described as a "real game changer" that "changed the way that readers thought about female writers." She also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

The passage discusses Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who plays for Worcestershire County Cricket Club. In 2016, during his second game for the county, he broke his finger, which was a setback for him and for Worcestershire's hopes of qualifying for a tournament. Despite this, there is "unfinished business" between Santner and Mitch, a reference to another player whose absence was a significant blow to Worcestershire's prospects.

Santner made his Test debut in 2015 and will return to play for the Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June 2017. He had a positive experience at Worcestershire, enjoying his time with the team despite the frustrating injury. Worcestershire has secured the services of Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season, indicating a focus on strengthening their bowling attack. Santner looks forward to returning to Worcestershire and making an impact with both bat and ball to make up for the lost time due to his injury.

The passage describes the tragic death of Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, who was killed by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, also known as Anna, had left a restaurant to retrieve a missing glove and was not with him at the time of the incident. The coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. The coroner noted that Barry's guard was lowered by inebriation and the car, which was stolen and had fake license plates, did not brake or stop. The evidence presented at the inquest was described as circumstantial but overwhelming, leading the coroner to conclude that Barry was unlawfully killed beyond reasonable doubt.

The inquest also revealed several concerning details about Ganna Ziuzina:

- She was 19 years younger than her husband.
- She tried to claim his assets within days of his death.
- Barry's family believes she was involved in his death to inherit his money and property.
- Initially, she claimed to be a teacher when she met Barry online in 2006,

The passage describes the situation of Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside, England, who requires experimental T-Cell Therapy for his health. Charlie has been battling illness since the age of three, and after experiencing a third relapse in April, traditional treatments in the UK were no longer viable. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed her gratitude for an anonymous donor who paid for Charlie's treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital in America, where the therapy is unavailable in the UK. The family was previously concerned about raising the funds necessary for the treatment, but the donor's generosity has alleviated this worry. The news of the donation was described as "completely overwhelming" by Sophie Fearns. Charlie's father, Rob Fearns, expressed extreme gratitude for the anonymous donor's selfless act, noting that the donor specifically requested to fund Charlie's treatment. The family is now awaiting confirmation of the treatment start date, which they expect to learn next week.

The passage discusses Apple's response to a series of hacks where intimate photos of celebrities were stolen from iCloud using third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple has introduced a two-step verification process to enhance security. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code that is either texted to a trusted mobile phone number or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app, in addition to their username and password. This extra step is optional and needs to be manually enabled by the user.

The two-step verification is intended to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts, even if a password is compromised. If a user fails to enter the code correctly, they are blocked from accessing iCloud services and making purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. However, they can regain access using a 14-character recovery key, which they must keep in a safe place.

Previously, Apple's two-step verification did not apply to iCloud back-ups, which could still be accessed by hackers using Elcomsoft's software. The new security measure prevents this kind of unauthorized access. Apple has also implemented a notification system that alerts account owners when a backup starts downloading, regardless of whether two-factor authentication

The passage discusses a potential deal where Danny Wright, a 30-year-old who was a runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, could acquire a 20% stake in Billericay Town Football Club. The finer details of the agreement have not been disclosed yet. Billericay Town are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. Wright has a background of playing non-league football for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable with investing £10,000 a week into the team. As part of these investments, the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the beginning of March.

The passage discusses a situation where Mike Ashley, the owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. This request comes after a letter from Iain Wright, the MP for Hartlepool, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The letter indicates that Mr. Ashley has until March 21 to respond. The committee has invited Mr. Ashley to a meeting at their base in Shirebrook to discuss the treatment of low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage. The letter also states that the committee typically meets in public and has offered alternative dates for the meeting, none of which Mr. Ashley has accepted. If he fails to respond or agree to attend, the committee reserves the right to take further action, including seeking the House of Commons' support in case of non-compliance. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request for a statement, but the company has previously committed to reviewing worker rights with oversight from Mr. Ashley, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

The passage discusses the efforts of Ilya Yashin and colleagues to complete a report titled "Putin. War," which was intended by the late Boris Nemtsov but never finished due to his assassination. The report compiles facts from Russian and foreign media about the conflict in Ukraine, particularly Crimea's annexation and the war in eastern Ukraine, to argue that President Vladimir Putin is responsible for waging war for his own ends. Despite Russia's denials of direct military involvement, the report claims Russian soldiers and equipment have been crucial in rebel victories in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report includes evidence from Russian soldiers and veterans who admit to being directed by Russian generals and receiving salaries of up to $2,000-3,000 per month. The opposition plans to print 2,000 copies initially but faces challenges in publishing and distribution due to fear among publishers and the public. The report aims to expose the extent of Russia's involvement in Ukraine and accuses Putin of using the conflict to boost his popularity, despite the limited impact of similar reports by Boris Nemtsov in the past.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem revealed that he died from head injuries. South Yorkshire Police arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield and they remain in custody.

The passage discusses the tension between the UK government and the devolved administrations, particularly focusing on Wales. Carwyn Jones, the first minister of Wales, expressed frustration over not being consulted on the Article 50 letter before its publication. He met with the Prime Minister Theresa May in Swansea last week but did not see the letter until Wednesday. Jones criticized the lack of respect shown to the devolved administrations and questioned the UK government's commitment to consulting them.

The UK government, represented by the Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns, defended their actions, stating that the Prime Minister has been in Wales frequently and that discussions about the letter's contents had been ongoing for months. Theresa May's letter to Donald Tusk mentioned the return of powers to the UK and the intention to consult on which powers should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The passage suggests that the focus might be more on Scotland, but the sentence is open to interpretation regarding Wales.

Key points of contention include the specifics of which powers will be devolved and whether financial support will follow these powers. Carwyn Jones fears that after 2020, there may not be funding to support devolved powers, possibly due to the uncertainty of a Labour government maintaining EU

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his "appalled" reaction to "mindless attacks" on police officers and the Newry community. According to a post on the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page, police were attacked while carrying out their duties. The passage describes the tragic story of Alice Ruggles, who was fatally attacked by her stalker, Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, last October. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed about her death by two Northumbria Police officers. They immediately suspected it was Dhillon due to his stalking behavior towards their daughter. During the trial at Newcastle Crown Court, it was revealed that Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and had stalked her. Alice's mother, Dr. Hills, expressed her guilt for having reassured her daughter over the phone that everything would be alright and that ignoring Dhillon would make him stop. Emma, Alice's sister, warned her mother that Dhillon might kill Alice, but Dr. Hills dismissed her concerns as an overreaction. After seeing the police, Dr. Hills realized the gravity of the situation and felt immense guilt for her earlier reassurances. The parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to remember Alice for her vibrant personality. The Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with a cost of £18bn, has received funding approval from EDF's board. Contracts were set to be signed on Friday, but the government announced it would "consider carefully" before backing the project. EDF's CEO canceled his visit to Hinkley Point following the government's comments. Critics are concerned about environmental damage, potential cost escalations, and the involvement of Chinese investors in one-third of the project. The government's decision to review the project has caused uncertainty and raised questions about the future of the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity needs and has been delayed by numerous reviews and financial concerns about EDF's ability to fund it. The approval of the project by EDF's board came after shareholders approved a €4bn (£3.4bn) share issue to finance the project, despite financial risks and resignations from EDF executives. Environmentalists oppose the project, citing its cost, potential for environmental damage, and the need for investment in renewable energy sources instead.

The newly designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the applicant's spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers express concern that naming a third party adds conflict and complexity to the divorce process. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name the third party. The guidance on the form suggests it is "not normally necessary" to name the adulterous partner, but the form's structure may encourage people to fill in this information. Naming the third party makes them part of the court case and can lead to delays and additional costs. Out of 100,000 divorces in 2015, 12,148 were due to adultery. Many clients seeking divorce for adultery want to involve the third party, but this can reflect poorly on the petitioner in court. Divorce applications must prove the marriage has broken down and give one of the accepted reasons, with adultery being one of them.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. Able seaman Charles Lewis, aged 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, was one of the recipients and expressed his feelings of being "honoured and delighted" to receive the medal. Initially, the Foreign Office in the UK had blocked the Russian government's attempt to honor the convoy veterans due to rules on foreign medals, but an exception was made last year, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the first medals during his visit to London. The Arctic Convoys were a series of missions during World War II where British ships transported supplies to northern Russia to aid the Soviet Union. These convoys were fraught with danger from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as harsh conditions like severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The convoys were considered by Winston Churchill to be the "worst journey in the world," yet they were crucial in providing the Soviet Union with the weapons and ammunition needed to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found that there are delays in starting unpaid work sentences for offenders and that many are not completing the required hours. Unpaid work, also known as community payback, is given for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work, which can include tasks like garden maintenance, decorating, or litter-picking. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. Problems identified include offenders not showing up for work, not completing their sentences, and a lack of organization. The government had ordered 10,000 orange bibs for offenders doing unpaid work under a re-branded scheme called "community payback." The coalition government promised to make unpaid work more physical and intense. Inspectors praised instances of high-quality work and cases where offenders gained skills. However, the chief inspector of probation, Paul Wilson, stated that unpaid work is often viewed as simply a punishment, which is a wasted opportunity

The passage discusses Russell Brand's reaction to The Sun newspaper branding him a "hypocrite" for his lifestyle contrasted with his political and economic activism. 2. **Medical Career and Research:** After returning from Vietnam, Venter pursued a medical career, focusing on research rather than practice. He excelled in decoding genes during the early days of the molecular biology revolution.

3. **Breakthroughs in Gene Decoding:** Venter realized that focusing on messenger molecules (RNA) instead of the entire DNA blueprint could speed up the process of decoding genes. He developed an automated decoding machine and switched his attention to RNA, significantly increasing the speed at which gene sequences could be produced.

The passage discusses a survey conducted by the School Food Trust, which found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they hadn't tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed reported that their children requested foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among the children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was prompted by a Mumsnet survey suggesting some parents gave their children packed lunches due to concerns about their children's fussiness. The passage describes the transfer of Alvaro Morata from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014, including a buyback clause for Real with a reported fee of up to 30m euros (£23m). The British supermarket giant Tesco is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to a private equity firm called Yucaipa. The passage discusses the significant reduction in the size of glaciers in the French Alps over the past few decades. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the total glacier area was approximately 375 square kilometers. By the late 2000s, this area had decreased to about 275 square kilometers, representing an average loss of roughly 26% over the last 40 years. The study was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting and involved the creation of a new French Alps glaciers inventory. This inventory assessed around 600 glaciers across several massifs, including the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, and Grande Rousse Arves massifs, as well as the Mont Blanc Massif. Manual delineation was used to verify satellite data, as automatic delineation can be inaccurate due to factors like debris cover and deep shadows. The greatest losses have been observed in the southern sectors, with glaciers almost disappearing in the Belledonne Massif and a threefold greater retreat in the Ecrins Massif compared to the Mont Blanc Massif. The passage discusses Scotland's women's national soccer team's efforts to qualify for the UEFA Women's Euro 2017 finals. Scotland has won all five qualifying matches and is set to play Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A win would significantly increase their chances of securing a spot in the finals, as the best six runners-up also qualify automatically. Scotland's forward, Lauren Evans, emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup in 2015. She expresses pride in the development of women's football in Scotland, noting that players returning from leagues abroad bring new skills and perspectives that benefit the national team's progress towards major competitions.

Stuart Campbell, a former computer games reviewer and Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London. The woman alleged harassment that took place over a two-year period, which she reported to a south London police station. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment. Stuart Campbell was released on bail, with a date in mid-September set for further inquiries. He accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation and insisted that nothing more serious than the tweets has occurred.
