Peta, an animal rights organization, wants to replace the mascot of Skegness, a town in Lincolnshire, UK, with a fish named "A Happy Plaice" as part of a campaign to promote ethical treatment of animals. The current mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, is a character from a 1908 poster commissioned by the Great Northern Railway to encourage visitors to Skegness. The poster featured the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." Peta argues that the Jolly Fisherman represents animal cruelty, citing the suffering of fish during fishing practices. Dawn Carr, a Peta spokesperson, believes that replacing the mascot with a fish that does not represent violence against sea animals would rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, acknowledges Peta's suggestion but believes the Jolly Fisherman is loved by the community and does not represent animal cruelty. He suggests that the town's council will consider the proposal but expresses reluctance to change something that is not broken.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old man, was released from a US facility in Cuba after a review panel concluded he was no longer a significant threat to the United States. He had been detained since 2002, originally arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, charges he denies. Al-Odah challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. He was released on a Kuwaiti government plane on Wednesday morning, expressing joy and excitement rather than bitterness or anger. His release was facilitated by the Periodic Review Board's determination in July that his continued detention was not necessary for US security. However, he will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait as part of the release terms. The Kuwaiti government had been pushing for the release of Kuwaiti detainees at Guantanamo. Al-Odah claimed he went to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release marks the first time an inmate has been freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. The passage describes the commemoration of Anzac Day, which honors the Australian and New Zealand forces' first major battle during World War One. Thousands attended a service at Hyde Park Corner, and up to 400 people participated in a parade before wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day began in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service. It has since become an important day for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians to honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. At the dawn service, Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK, spoke about the Gallipoli landings and the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops. A parade featuring members of veterans' associations and schoolchildren reading prayers concluded with the singing of the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula was one of the bloodiest battles of World War One, with the allied operation aiming to remove the Ottoman Empire from the war.

The passage describes the return of Ross Clarkson to St Mirren FC in the Scottish Championship. Clarkson, a 30-year-old player, rejoined the club in July for a second spell. The passage describes the case of Timothy Geaney, who admitted taking or permitting the taking of images between April 2004 and February 2014. These images were primarily of young boys in erotic poses, without any sexual activity. Geaney was sentenced to a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register. He was also required to participate in a special program for sex offenders. In February 2023, a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing determined that Geaney's actions were fundamentally incompatible with being a registered teacher due to his involvement in an industry that violates and abuses children. The panel found that his conduct over a lengthy period demonstrated a pattern of behavior, and they concluded that there was a strong likelihood of his offending behavior recurring. As a result, they found Geaney unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register. Geaney, who was 69 at the time of his sentencing, was not present at the hearing and was prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

The passage describes an incident where a fire occurred at a site on Duncan Street on 2 March, leading to disruptions in train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire. The fire service noted that the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, but they had raised concerns with the EA about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA, after considering these concerns and conducting joint visits with fire safety officers, decided to revoke the environmental permit for the site. This decision will take effect on 7 August, after which Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited will no longer be able to operate from the site. The company is still required to remove all the waste, and the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses Syria's compliance with the destruction of its chemical weapons stockpile, which it is supposed to complete by the end of June. England secured a comprehensive victory over Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning by an innings and 180 runs. They achieved this by making a massive total of 589-8 declared in their first innings and then dismissing Pakistan for a mere 234 in their second innings. Root also took four catches and bowled a spell that resulted in a wicket. The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. The passage describes the experiences of a man who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the civil war in Sierra Leone, which began in 1991 when he was 15 years old. He eventually found hope through a preacher named Richard Cole, who founded Lifeline Nehemiah, a project aimed at giving hope and a home to those who felt they had lost it. The preacher encouraged him to continue his education and to believe that he could contribute to rebuilding his nation.

When the Ebola crisis hit Sierra Leone in 2014, the man and his team, inspired by the same spirit of giving back, transformed their clinic into a center for Ebola education and support. They educated over 10,000 people, provided food to 11,000 families, and set up an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives.

The passage concludes with the man expressing his changed life perspective, his regret for past actions, and his confidence in the future.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court accused eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, of gross negligence manslaughter due to her alleged failure to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and refer him for further investigation. This failure allegedly led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution claims Vinnie's death was preventable and would have been prevented had Ms. Rose done her job properly. Her conduct is alleged to have been so far below the expected standard that it was criminal. The trial continues.

The passage discusses Apple's response to a series of hacks where intimate photos of celebrities were stolen from iCloud using third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple has introduced a two-step verification process to enhance security. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via the Find My iPhone app in addition to their password when accessing iCloud on a new device. This step is optional but is recommended to prevent unauthorized access. The two-step verification is designed to stop tools like Phone Password Breaker from accessing iCloud accounts. Apple's owner acknowledges that this new security measure makes it difficult to bypass and that users will receive an email notification when a backup starts downloading, regardless of whether two-factor authentication is enabled. However, there are concerns about the recovery key, which is needed if the trusted device is lost or stolen. The expert suggests that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all companies, not just Apple, to prevent unauthorized access. Apple plans to increase awareness about the importance of using stronger passwords and two-factor authentication.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season by hitting eight three-pointers in the Warriors' 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed by an Amtrak train heading north on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred on tracks owned by Norfolk Southern around 9:50 AM. The train, Amtrak's Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City with 166 passengers on board. None of the passengers were injured, but a man who became ill during the delay received treatment. Authorities stated that the couple was pronounced dead at the scene. The train was delayed for about three hours before resuming its journey. A man who knew the couple said they might have lived in a homeless camp and struggled to cross the tracks with their belongings in a grocery cart. He emphasized the importance of kindness towards those in dire straits, urging not to condemn them as they have hearts. Durham is approximately 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, Raleigh. The usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for U.S. citizenship. After declining health forced him to retire, he was not granted citizenship and is now at risk of deportation to Colombia, where he fears for his life. Toro helped the DEA capture key figures, including Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega, and was instrumental in several undercover stings worldwide. Despite his contributions, the DEA refused to assist him with citizenship after he went public with his plight. He is currently living in the U.S. illegally and is concerned about his safety. DEA agent Mike McManus, who worked with Toro, believes he deserves to stay in the U.S. and live a peaceful life after his service. Toro is trying to secure a green card or passport but is in a precarious situation with his final temporary visa expired and no social security benefits available until he obtains one of these documents. He fears going into hiding if necessary and expressed his desire to simply receive the citizenship that was promised to him.

The passage discusses a situation where the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN), a U.S. body that regulates internet addresses, is looking into the actions of a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., which is using the new '.sucks' domain name to exploit celebrities and companies by charging them exorbitant sums to remove their names from these domains. The passage describes the resolution of a 27-year-old cold case involving the discovery of a baby boy's body in a pond in the village of Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, England. The baby was found wrapped in a Sainsbury's bag floating on the water on June 5, 1988. The case remained unsolved for decades despite a post-mortem examination that failed to determine a cause of death.

In 2015, a DNA sample taken from the exhumed body matched a woman's DNA profile, leading police to her identity. The woman, who had concealed her pregnancy from her family and friends, explained that the baby was stillborn and that she had placed the body in the pond shortly after the stillbirth. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but was later released without charge after providing this explanation.

The woman's account was corroborated by DNA evidence and a second post-mortem, which found no evidence of foul play. The baby was reburied at St Peter's Church in Weasenham St Peter on June 5, 2015, the 26th anniversary of his discovery, and was named Peter.

The passage describes an incident where Kristopher Hicks, a passenger in a taxi, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving vehicle. The driver, Michael Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, the driver continued for almost a mile before Hicks jumped out of the moving car, which was traveling at more than 20mph. As a result, Hicks suffered devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother.

The family took the driver, Michael Young, to the High Court, where Mr. Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling Hicks to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50% of the family's requested amount, which is thought to be "hundreds of thousands of pounds."

The judge concluded that Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to avoid the fare and intended to return him to the taxi rank to cause inconvenience, not intending any harm. However, this action created a significant risk to life and limb, as demonstrated by the incident.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout this Saturday in New Jersey. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago and is targeting a title shot. He believes the key to defeating Machida is to be aggressive and dominate the fight, as Machida tends to "run around and dance." Rockhold plans to "cut him off, slowly progress, and make him fight my fight." He acknowledges Machida's skill and respect for his fighting style but is determined to showcase his own style and dominate the match. Rockhold's last victory was against Michael Bisping in November, and Machida's was against CB Dollaway in Brazil. Machida is confident in his ability to defeat Rockhold and earn a title shot, believing that he can apply his technique to stop Rockhold and that the winner of their fight deserves a title shot. He has been training hard for eight weeks with good preparation, including training with other fighters like Glover Teixeira. Machida is feeling well-prepared and confident in his ability to perform well in the fight.

The passage describes an incident where a light general aviation aircraft, a Piper Aerostar, attempted to land at the aero acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear. The footage captures the plane touching down on the runway without its gear, skidding along the tarmac on its belly. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, who has reportedly been flying for almost 50 years, managed to realize his mistake and re-engage the engines, taking off again. The plane then flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common cause of such incidents, known as a gear-up landing, is human error, where the pilot forgets to extend the landing gear before landing. Another cause can be mechanical failure, such as a failed electric motor or hydraulic actuator. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the incident.

The passage discusses Manuel Pellegrini's stance on Yaya Toure, a Manchester City midfielder whose performance this season has been a source of disappointment for both Pellegrini and the club. The passage describes the case of Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian man dubbed the "Godfather of Uxbridge" who was wanted in Italy for his involvement with the Mafia. He fled to the UK in the 1990s and lived under the alias Marc Skinner. In 1999, he was convicted in absentia in Italy and sentenced to seven years in prison for being a member of the Cosa Nostra.

Rancadore was arrested in 2013 in the UK based on an European Arrest Warrant. However, due to concerns about his heart condition and the conditions in Italian prisons, District Judge Howard Riddle initially ruled against extradition. The case went through multiple legal proceedings, with Rancadore's extradition being denied on several occasions due to concerns about his health and the conditions in Italian prisons.

The passage explains that Rancadore's conviction was set to expire last October because Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished after more than double the penalty has passed. This means that for a seven-year sentence, the conviction would expire after 14 years. The Italian authorities did not contest this legal argument, and the European Arrest Warrant was withdrawn.

The passage tells the story of Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter, Marcia, was murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. It also mentions that Marcia's body was found 150 yards from her home, in a rarely used, windowless garage, under a shower curtain and a child's wading pool. The passage also notes that in 1979, a neighbor was initially charged with the murder but was later acquitted due to lack of evidence.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete his career Grand Slam. He hopes to use Augusta National as a sanctuary from the hype and pressure, focusing on his game and playing his best.

The passage discusses the alarming rise in hospital admissions of children born with brain damage due to exposure to alcohol in the womb, with 272 youngsters being admitted to hospitals in England over the past 12 months. Experts warn that the actual number of children affected could be much higher, estimating that around 7,500 babies a year in the UK might suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure. Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is irreversible, as highlighted by the case of Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old girl who requires assistance for daily activities and will never be able to live independently. The passage also mentions other health issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy, such as liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption to no more than two units no more than twice a week, but Elizabeth Mitchell, from the National Organization for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome, advocates for an alcohol-free pregnancy policy.

The passage describes an incident where a masked robber, Shaun Andrew Mckerry, attempted to rob a store in County Durham, England, using an axe. The passage tells the story of Valerie Jackson, whose four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare congenital skin disease. RJ's skin appears red and inflamed, covered in dry, scaly skin that resembles burns. The disease is so rare that only 70 people worldwide are known to have it.

Valerie has to regularly apply creams to RJ to prevent his skin from drying out. Despite her efforts, RJ was recently mistaken for a child who had been abused when a stranger reported her to the police. This happened while Valerie was out shopping and surrounded by armed police who had been called by a concerned member of the public.

Valerie explains that Netherton's syndrome causes RJ's skin to appear red and scaly, and that he has been treated as an outcast, being denied entry to play centers and facing cruel jibes from people in the street. She describes the challenges of caring for RJ, including the need to cleanse and moisturize his skin regularly and the difficulty of managing his itchy, sensitive skin.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding a series of "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements by the online fitness store Protein World. The campaign features a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield, and the ads have sparked outrage from feminists and body image campaigners. A Change.org petition calling for the removal of the posters has garnered over 50,000 signatures. The passage discusses a situation where rail firms have planned fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite the main party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened regarding an 87% fare increase on a train route through his Witney constituency. The prime minister has requested First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review their decision to almost double some fares. Unregulated fares, which make up around half of rail companies' total revenue, can be increased during three windows each year. FGW has defended the fare hike by stating it aims to align the north Cotswolds route with other services and has offered cheaper advanced single tickets as an alternative. Virgin Trains has also defended its fare increases, claiming that the vast majority affect "Virgin Trains-only fares" which are at least 20% cheaper than those offered by rival firms. The passage highlights the political and consumer backlash against these fare hikes, contrasting with election promises of fare freezes and the complexities of fare structures in the rail industry.

The passage describes an incident where former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown through his front door by vandals. The attack occurred while John and his new wife Elaine, 54, were writing thank you cards in their home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The couple had been married just three weeks prior to the incident. John went to confront the attackers after noticing stones being thrown at his property. Upon opening the door, he was directly hit by a brick, resulting in serious injury to his left eye and an open wound to his forehead. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. John, a retired HGV driver who previously served with the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers during the Irish Troubles, expressed his shock and fear about feeling unsafe in his own home. Police are investigating the incident, suspecting it could be a case of "yobs messing around," but emphasizing the seriousness of the consequences of the attack. Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam stated that the brick was thrown "directly" at John and that there appears to be no known motive. The couple plans to move to Southport due to the traumatic incident.

Harley underwent intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumour, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. After battling the disease for a year, Harley was given the all-clear by doctors, marking a year since his diagnosis.

The passage describes how Gary Locke, a 41-year-old former Hearts boss, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after an interim period following the resignation of Allan Johnston at the start of February. Locke took over the team last summer as an assistant to Johnston and has since lost only one out of seven games he has managed. A Florida mother named Jessica Kemp alleges that her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, was threatened with suspension from Seminole County Elementary School due to the use of essential oils. Logan wears these oils, which are applied by Jessica to help him stay calm and focused, as he has a medical condition. The oils, produced by Doterra, have scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. A teacher's aide reportedly complained about the smell, leading to a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. Jessica argues that she can use chemicals on her son but cannot use natural products with a smell. Despite the threat of punishment, Jessica intends to continue using the oils, believing they have a positive impact on Logan. On Thursday, the Lake County School District stated they would not suspend Logan, categorizing the issue as a "health issue." Doterra, the company that produces the oils, has been contacted for comment.

The passage describes a devastating fire that occurred at a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, Long Island, on Wednesday at 3 pm. The fire destroyed 90 condos, and the intense flames were so hot that they melted the paint off nearby buildings. The cause of the fire is unknown, and it spread rapidly, with smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews were dispatched but were unable to enter the summer homes due to the intensity of the blaze. Janice Sklarek, who owns an apartment in the Sandpiper complex, which is open from May to November, described the scene as her and her partner rushed back to the property. The building manager, Rob Taber, who lived and worked in the complex, expressed his devastation at losing everything. A witness, Dave Rose, noted the fire's visibility from three miles away. The Westhampton fire chief, Ross Donneson, mentioned that the wind was offshore, aiding visibility for the firefighters. The fire department is investigating claims that the fire may have started near a car parked by the complex.

The queen, who is 88 years old, enjoyed a ride in the spring sunshine this morning, trotting through Windsor Great Park on her faithful black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma. She was accompanied by a groom on another fell pony and chose to wear a silk scarf instead of a helmet, as she has never worn a riding helmet due to concerns about her hair. The queen has a long history with horses, having first ridden a shetland pony named Peggy at the age of four. She has bred fell ponies at Hampton Court and has a stud at Balmoral that specializes in highland ponies. Despite a niggling knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and often visits her Windsor stables. The fell pony breed, which includes Carltonlima Emma, is one of the oldest in the world, dating back to the neolithic period. These docile, hardy ponies, which are typically black, grey, or bay and stand between 13 and 14 hands high, were valued by the Carvetii tribe and later by the Romans and Vikings. The fell pony's role has evolved over centuries, from being used as pack animals to transporting iron ore and coal during the industrial revolution,

The passage describes a tragic incident where a 55-year-old man, Leon Yeaman, was killed by a single punch from his 28-year-old neighbour, Phillip Pama, during an argument over noise levels in front of their homes in North Brisbane. Phillip Pama, a shift worker who was asleep at the time of the commotion, confronted Leon Yeaman, who was making a lot of noise in his yard at around 9 PM on Thursday. According to Pama's defense lawyer, Bruce Peters, Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at the world at large. The confrontation escalated when Pama grabbed Yeaman by the hand and hit out "blindly" as he was being pushed. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene at around 11 PM. Neighbours described Yeaman as a kind and generous man, while his friend mentioned he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed playing loud music. Phillip Pama was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail, with conditions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and reporting to the police station twice a week. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

The passage describes the case of Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher in Russia who was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya. The relationship between the teacher and the student ended when Vanya began dating one of his classmates. Simonova, feeling jilted and seeking revenge, asked a friend to find someone willing to carry out the murder for 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400).

Police, aware of the plot, set up a sting operation. They sent an undercover officer to pose as a hitman during a meeting with Simonova in Shatura, a city near Moscow. A hidden camera recorded the exchange, capturing Simonova's detailed instructions for the murder, including her desire for Vanya to suffer unbearable pain and bleed to death. She specified that his arms and legs should be broken, and his kidneys damaged, but his face should not be touched. She also wanted to be present to "finish him" after the assailant had inflicted the injuries.

After handing over some expenses money to the undercover officer, Simonova was arrested by armed police in her car. She was searched

The passage describes Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, sharing insights into his personal life and beliefs. Key points include:

1. Mourinho talks to God every day, but the conversations are about personal matters, not football.
2. He and his family have experienced poverty, which has shaped their perspective on privilege and the need to help others.
3. Mourinho is an ambassador for the World Food Programme and has worked with the organization to combat hunger.
4. He tries to maintain a clear separation between his professional life as Chelsea's manager and his personal life.
5. Mourinho has a strong faith in God and attends church regularly in Portugal but not in the UK.
6. He admits to making mistakes in his professional life due to the competitive and emotional nature of football management but insists he is a good person overall.
7. Chelsea is currently top of the league, and they are set to play Queens Park Rangers (QPR) this weekend.
8. Mourinho was fined £25,000 by football authorities for accusing the referees of being part of a campaign against Chelsea after a booking for diving against Southampton.
9. Mourinho attended the Hunger Games premiere with his wife and children, emphasizing his personal life.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for its April 1, 2021, episode after an eight-year absence. At 91 years old, Barker appeared energetic and performed the first segment, "Lucky Seven," before handing over the hosting duties to Drew Carey, who concluded the show. Barker's return was a surprise to the contestants, who were used to Carey's hosting. Despite not having been on the show for a significant period, Barker's performance was seamless, showcasing his continued ability to engage with the show's format and audience.

The passage describes the arrest of an off-duty Secret Service agent named Arthur Baldwin. He was arrested early on Friday, around 12:30 AM, on a residential street in southeastern Washington, D.C., for allegedly attempting to break into a house. Baldwin was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave following the arrest. He is a member of the Foreign Missions Branch, which is part of the State Department and deals with the U.S.'s diplomatic activities. Baldwin was scheduled to be arraigned on Friday afternoon, but the passage does not mention if he had an attorney or provided a contact number. The incident comes two days after a high-ranking Secret Service supervisor was also placed on leave for alleged misconduct, which is currently being investigated by the police and the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General. Additionally, the Secret Service is already investigating an incident from March 4 where two high-ranking officials are accused of driving into a secure area at the White House after a night of drinking.

The passage describes an incident where Atif Saeed, a freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. He spotted the lion in the distance while at the city's safari park and decided to leave his car to get closer for a better shot. Armed only with his camera, he crept up to within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to avoid detection. The clicking sound of his camera shutter alerted the lion to his presence, causing the lion to aggressively jump towards him. Saeed managed to scramble into his car just in time. He later expressed that he was laughing at the time but now, thinking back, he's not sure he would do it again, acknowledging the close encounter.

The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman who died in Brooklyn last month. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Despite efforts by paramedics, she could not be revived and was pronounced dead that evening. The tattoo, which is a heart with the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within it and topped with a rose, is distinctive and is hoped to help identify the woman. The NYPD is seeking the public's help to identify her through the Crime Stoppers hotline at 800-577-TIPS, pending the results of the medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, who couldn't afford to buy property upon their return from the UK in 2009, decided to build their own home on the back of an old flatbed truck. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed and spent a year and a half transforming it into a cozy, solar-powered two-bedroom home made of wood and steel. The couple now lives in Nelson, New Zealand, in a home that is surrounded by nature, featuring aromatic cypress wood inside and majestic trees and a babbling brook outside. The home is nearly self-sufficient, powered mostly by solar panels, with gas for the stove and hot water, and water sourced from a nearby spring. The total cost of the project was around $25,000, and the couple plans to build another similar home in the future. They love their unique living space, which includes a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other creature comforts.

The passage discusses research findings that indicate children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not share or do not use iPads at all. The study was conducted by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University, who worked with 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district over an academic year. The results showed that students who shared iPads scored around 30 points higher than those who used the devices individually, and significantly higher than those who did not use iPads at all. The study suggests that it is the collaborative learning facilitated by sharing the iPads that contributes to the improved literacy test scores, rather than just the act of collaboration itself. The researcher, Courtney Blackwell, recommends that schools reconsider how they use tablets, especially in early grades, to maximize the effectiveness of technology in education. These findings challenge the skepticism expressed by the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers regarding the use of technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes.

The passage describes a piglet born with no hind legs, which has become an internet sensation due to a video showing it walking on its front trotters. The piglet, affectionately nicknamed "Super Pig," has learned to balance remarkably well, despite the challenges posed by its unique condition. It interacts with its full-legged siblings and has attracted attention from villagers and tourists alike since its birth in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China. Farmer Ms. Duan discovered the piglet's condition when it was feeding among its littermates.

The piglet's ability to walk on two front legs has captured the hearts of thousands online, drawing comparisons to another internet sensation: a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that became famous for walking on its front paws. Both animals have inspired awe and admiration from people who have seen videos of them navigating their environments in unconventional ways. The passage highlights the resilience and adaptability of these animals, as well as the fascination they have sparked in the public.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured on Sunday during the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana. He works as a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing. The incident occurred when Francesco Dracone, who was coming in for tires and fuel on lap 25, spun while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment, where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was later released. The race was marked by many cars struggling with traction due to rain that had fallen before the green flag. Dracone did not finish the race and ended up in 23rd place.

The passage describes a horrific incident where a husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, a dancer known by her stage name Amanda Bueno. The crime took place in the garden of their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The husband confessed to the murder, stating that his jealousy over men looking at his wife was the motive for the brutal attack.

The attack was captured on CCTV, showing Milton dragging Cicera's limp body into the garden, where he repeatedly smashed her head into concrete paving 11 times and then punched her in the face 10 times. After leaving her battered and unconscious on the ground, he went into the house, returned with a handgun, and shot her five times at point-blank range.

A horrified neighbor, Lelio Maya Puga, 33, heard a violent argument before the incident went silent, followed by gunshots. The neighbor knew Cicera from her involvement with a dance group called Jaula das Gostozuedas, which the neighbor had attended and was a fan of.

After the murder, Milton stole a neighbor's car and crashed it during his getaway. Police found

The passage discusses Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author known for her book "I Quit Sugar," who has shared her personal struggle with mental illness, particularly depression and anxiety. She revealed in a candid interview that her anxiety led her to feel her life was no longer worth living, with feelings exacerbated by stress, thyroid disease, and a sense of isolation due to not having a husband or children. Wilson experienced these issues in her younger years and has since found some peace with her mental health struggles.

Wilson believes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial for better support and intervention for women affected by stress and anxiety. She describes anxiety as becoming the "new depression," reflecting its growing prevalence. According to the Beyond Blue report, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and depression and anxiety are often interconnected, with one condition potentially leading to the other.

For those in need of help, the passage encourages contacting Beyondblue on 1300 224 636 or Lifeline on 13 11 14.

The passage describes the case of Elena Curtin, a pregnant Oregon woman who was charged with second-degree assault after she used a crowbar to attack her boyfriend's former girlfriend in November 2014. The incident occurred when Curtin returned home to find her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. When Curtin asked her to leave and she refused, Curtin reacted by beating her with the crowbar, striking her in the head and arm.

The charges against Curtin were dropped on Monday because prosecutors deemed her actions to be "completely justified in her outrage," given the circumstances. Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, argued that the ex-girlfriend was "jealous and bitter" and had made it her mission to make Curtin's life miserable over a two-year period. The ex-girlfriend had previously harassed Curtin, stolen from her, and plotted to drag her boyfriend back into his addiction to heroin.

Curtin gave birth to her child in January. The boyfriend, who is the father of her child, has not been involved in the new child

The passage describes a pit bull named Gemma, who lives in California. She is filmed at home being fed treats, but her owner tries to trick her by adding a broccoli spear to the mix. Gemma reacts with visible disgust, chomping on the broccoli only to spit it out on the floor. The passage expresses concern that the two children she lives with might follow her example and not learn to love their greens. The rest of the time, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family. The key points are: Gemma is a pit bull, she lives in California, she was filmed being fed treats with a broccoli trick, she dislikes broccoli, and there is a concern about the children's dietary habits based on her behavior.

The summary of the passage is: HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link led to a porn site that had taken over the URL of the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was discontinued in 2011. The URL was allowed to expire, and the porn site registered it, causing any traffic intended for the awards page to be redirected to the adult content. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website after discovering the mistake. The bank denied any association with the external site and offered an apology for the inconvenience caused. HSBC's internet banking service allows customers to perform various transactions, and the bank insisted its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy from Maryland called 911 when a fire broke out in his home on Sunday morning. He and his 9-year-old sister were trapped in a second-floor bedroom because the hallway was too hot to pass through. During the 11-minute 911 call, the boy stayed calm and provided the dispatcher with information about the situation, including the presence of his older brother, mother, and step-father in the house. He also comforted his sister when she expressed fear, telling her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters were able to rescue the siblings by entering the home through the back and breaking a window to the room. Firefighter Kenny Ward handed the boy out the window and then gave his gas mask to the girl. Both children were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own.

The passage describes remarkable images of blue fluorescent algae illuminating Australia's east coast, specifically at Jervis Bay, New South Wales. The phenomenon was captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who likened the sight to a "beautiful supernatural scene." This glowing effect is due to millions of plankton emitting light, particularly a type of single-celled phytoplankton called Noctiluca scintillans. This algae species is known for its bioluminescence, which it uses as a defense mechanism against other types of algae, such as diatoms.

A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach back in August 2014. According to Iain Suthers, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, the glowing is a natural occurrence that happens in the spring and autumn in 90% of cases. The luminescence is a result of the algae's carnivorous nature, which preys on diatoms, and serves as a defense mechanism against predators.

The passage emphasizes that there is no need to be concerned about the glowing algae, as it is a natural and common phenomenon.

The passage discusses a new development in breast cancer treatment where genetic markers in the tumor are tested to determine the aggressiveness of the cancer and predict the likelihood of recurrence. These tests, such as the Endopredict test, can provide results within days after surgery, indicating whether a patient has a low risk of cancer returning. For women with a very low risk, as low as 5%, the test suggests that chemotherapy may not be necessary, as their chances of recurrence are comparable to or better than those who undergo chemotherapy.

Chemotherapy, while effective in killing cancer cells, comes with severe side effects that can be difficult for patients to endure. The prospect of chemotherapy is often more daunting for some patients than the surgery itself. Historically, chemotherapy has been a standard treatment for most breast cancer patients following tumor removal to prevent recurrence. However, experts have long believed that the risk of recurrence varies significantly among patients, and for some, chemotherapy may not be essential.

The new tests offer patients the opportunity to make an informed decision about chemotherapy based on their individual risk. These tests are currently available privately at a cost of approximately £2,500. Surgeons and breast cancer specialists advocate for the tests to become available on the NHS, arguing that

The passage discusses the evacuation of pregnant women from Royal Navy ships, revealing that over 25 women have been airlifted for this reason in the last nine years. The ship HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medical evacuations. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, which was humorously nicknamed "HMS Lustful" by the crew before its decommissioning. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a "no touching" rule, suggesting that pregnancies occurred either before boarding or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK after claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. A strict "no touching" rule implies that any pregnancies would have occurred before boarding or during leave. Women have been serving in the Royal Navy since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female. Three women became the first female submariners in the Royal Navy last May. The passage also mentions that nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering they were pregnant, and a total of 99 servicewomen were evacuated from various operations between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy. The passage discusses a concerning incident in Japan involving a drone found on the rooftop of the Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. This discovery occurred on the same day that a Japanese court approved the restart of two nuclear reactors, which is a controversial move due to the lingering public fear from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. The drone, which was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium, a radioactive material commonly associated with nuclear reactors, was found on the roof of Shinzo Abe's residence. The presence of cesium suggests a deliberate attempt to link the drone to nuclear materials, raising concerns about potential terrorism, particularly in light of upcoming events like the Olympics and the G7 summit. The Japanese government is taking this incident as a warning sign and plans to review drone operation regulations and enhance security measures to prevent future drone-related terrorist threats.

The passage describes Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province in China, who takes extraordinary measures to care for his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. Lu is concerned that if he leaves his mother alone at home, she might get lost due to her condition. His father recently passed away, leaving Lu as the primary caregiver for his mother.

Every day, Lu wakes up at 5 AM to take his mother to work with him. He places her on the back seat of his motorbike and secures them together with a sash to prevent her from falling off during the four-kilometer ride to his workplace. The journey takes an hour, during which they chat to ensure her comfort and safety.

At work, Lu's employers have provided a room for his mother, and he frequently checks on her to make sure she hasn't wandered off. He feels a strong sense of duty to care for his mother, as she devoted her life to raising him and his siblings.

Lu expresses his devotion to his mother by saying, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple." He recalls how his mother carried him on her back to

The passage discusses a significant increase in heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans, particularly among women. The study, conducted by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, reveals that heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, with the increase largely driven by women's drinking habits. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines heavy drinking as consuming an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion.

The study found that binge drinking rates among women increased more than seven times the rate among men over the decade. The increases in drinking patterns are attributed to changing social norms, where women are increasingly engaging in binge drinking to catch up with men. The study also highlights regional differences, with Madison County, ID, having the lowest binge drinking rate at 6 percent and Menominee, WI, having the highest at 36 percent.

Despite the increase in heavy and binge drinking, the overall percentage of people who drink alcohol has remained relatively unchanged. The study notes that excessive drinking costs the U.S. more than $

The passage discusses concerns raised by UN officials about the overuse of caesarean sections, stating that they should only be performed when medically necessary due to the risks involved, including infections and even death. The rate of caesarean sections in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, with just over a quarter of births now being by caesarean. This increase includes a growing number of women choosing planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. WHO experts recommend that the caesarean section rate should ideally be between 10% and 15%, citing the potential for significant complications, disability, or death, as well as the diversion of resources from other patient needs. The cost of a planned caesarean in the NHS is significantly higher than that of a natural birth. The passage contrasts WHO's stance with current NHS guidelines, which allow for caesareans without medical justification, including for women with tokophobia (extreme fear of childbirth) and other conditions. WHO warns that caesareans are being performed too frequently and that the risks are often underestimated. Previous research has indicated that as many as one in ten caesareans result in infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard and living there for at least a week. She sold items belonging to the owners at a yard sale. Michelle Filkins has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered her in his $800,000 summer home in Edgartown. When confronted, Filkins claimed ownership, then fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when Conklin called the police. A large glass window to the front door had been broken and covered by a blanket. Filkins was arrested several hours later after attempting to return thinking Conklin had left. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins outside with items from the home. The Edgartown Police Department is asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the police department. They emphasize that anyone who purchased items is also a victim and will assist in seeking restitution through the court case. Anyone with information should contact the police department at 508-627-4343.

The passage describes an incident where Bella Crooke, from Melbourne, lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. The next morning, she called her number and a security guard informed her that the phone had been handed in to Albury Police Station on the New South Wales-Victoria border. Upon realizing the phone was unlocked, the police officers on duty used it to post a series of humorous selfies and messages on Bella's Facebook page, including a photo of the phone in a "holding cell" and playful comments about charging the battery and the phone's good behavior. They waited for Bella to collect her phone, which she did without having to provide her name as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police's humorous approach to the situation was well-received, with Bella's friends sharing the post and labeling the officers as "legends." Bella has since secured her phone with a password. The post was shared widely, and the police even engaged in text message exchanges with friends asking if Bella had her phone back, further showcasing their playful interaction.

The passage describes a tragic incident where a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed during a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso wetland park, eastern South Africa. The baby hippo strayed into the path of the fighting adults and was thrown into the air by one of the males. The mother hippo watched in horror as her calf was dragged along the water surface and eventually died from its injuries hours later. Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, witnessed the incident and noted that the mother hippo had been trying to protect her calf from the other hippos, especially the sub-adults, fearing they might be too rough with her baby. However, despite her efforts, one of the sub-adult hippos grabbed the calf, and in the ensuing struggle, the baby was fatally injured and flicked into the air before dying. The cause of death was attributed to the injuries sustained during the fight.

The passage describes a three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, which is being sold for £575,000. This price is significantly lower than the typical cost of similar properties in the area, primarily because the lease has only three years remaining. The annual cost of the property, if purchased under this lease, would be £191,000 per year, or £15,000 per month, which is comparable to the market rate for renting a similar property in Knightsbridge. However, the real value of the property lies in its potential once the lease is extended. If a buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The apartment is described as "bright and well-proportioned," with 1,990 sq/ft of space, featuring three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and a utility room, along with amenities like a lift, parking, and a communal garden. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson for £575,000, and there are two such maisonettes being sold, both in need of modernization. Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada on Friday night, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The outage began in the early evening on the east coast and late afternoon on the west coast. The company did not specify the cause but said the issue was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. Stores were expected to open for "business as usual" on Saturday.

The glitch prevented credit card transactions and ringing up sales, but cash was still accepted at some locations. Customers took to Twitter to spread the word about the free drinks, with many sharing photos of their free beverages. Some stores closed early to avoid giving away free products.

Starbucks issued a statement apologizing for the inconvenience and confirmed that the outage also affected their Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. The company had posted record quarterly earnings the day before, with net revenues of $4.6 billion. Despite the setback, Starbucks shares gained 4.4% to $51.50 following the earnings announcement.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of west Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. These locations are also used for radicalizing Muslims, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. The individuals involved in these activities participate in seemingly ordinary community activities but have an ulterior motive. The issue of Islamic extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998 when a group of 10 extremists trained in Powys, which is also used by the British military for training due to its rugged terrain that prepares soldiers, including elite forces like the SAS, for warfare. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed in Wales, and in 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for plotting a Mumbai-style attack in Britain. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is believed to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanybydder, which is thought to have been set up by Iraqi clerics. The passage describes the discovery of an Omura's whale on a west Australian beach, which is the first sighting in the state and the second in Australia. The whale was a juvenile female measuring 5.68 meters. Initially, identifying the species was difficult for wildlife staff, who confirmed it through DNA profiling. The Omura's whale is a rare species, first described in scientific journals in 2003, and is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters, including Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. It has unique skeletal features, such as 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The discovery is significant for whale scientists as it provides an opportunity to learn more about the species. The carcass was buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possibly for public display in museums.

The passage discusses the notion that hormones should be considered when evaluating a female presidential candidate, specifically Hillary Clinton. It highlights the viewpoint of Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman who expressed concern that Clinton's hormones might make her irrational and prone to starting unnecessary wars. The passage contrasts this with historical examples of male leaders whose hormones have impaired their decision-making, citing studies that show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks.

The passage also touches on the broader issue of gender bias in the workplace and its impact on women's potential to hold leadership positions. It mentions that despite women outnumbering men in certain educational and professional settings, societal bias limits their advancement. The article argues that this bias is deeply ingrained and affects everything from corporate boards to academic evaluations.

The passage concludes by challenging the idea that women are unfit for leadership roles and emphasizes the benefits of gender equality in various aspects of society, including the economy, families, and corporate teams. It uses the example of Kim Campbell, who became Canada's first female prime minister in 1993, to correct an earlier mistake in the article about Canada's political history.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill in various television dramas, is selling his extensive collection of antiques at a £100,000 auction. The collection, amassed over his career, includes more than 200 items, reflecting his interests in military history, classic literature, and medieval longbows. Among the highlights are a hand-painted 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the bow. The auction, organized by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, will take place on Saturday in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, with 238 lots up for sale. Hardy, who lives in the Cotswolds, expressed sadness at downsizing and losing his treasured library but found solace in entrusting his collection to Dominic Winter. He has a rich history, having studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Magdalen College, Oxford, and published two books on the history of the longbow. Hardy's acting career spans several decades, including roles with Richard Burton, Laurence Olivier, John Gielgud,

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. The body was discovered after a family member from out of state called for a well-being check. Police have confirmed foul play and are looking for Shemansky, who is on the run. He has a history of bipolar mental illness, attempted suicide, and battery on law enforcement, and was on parole. His estranged wife, Diana Knowles Dunlop, confirmed the missed visit and stated he was on parole. Neighbors believe the stress of his divorce proceedings may have contributed to the incident. Shemansky allegedly asked for a glass of water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder and fled on foot without any provisions or medication. Authorities are urging anyone with information about his whereabouts to contact them at 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, who chose to bypass the usual bidding process due to what they saw as a "unique strategic opportunity to host the IAAF World Championships for the first time in the USA." Eugene previously lost its bid to host the 2019 event to Doha, Qatar, but a recent presentation convinced the governing body that Eugene is capable of staging a world championships. The IAAF President, Lamine Diack, expressed delight in the decision, stating that it represents a strategic choice to access a key market and supports the global development of athletics. The 2021 event will be the first time the IAAF World Championships are held in the USA.

The passage describes the case of Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, who targeted Mehmet Hassan, a 56-year-old professional gambler, at a London casino. Granger befriended Hassan after spotting him flashing a roll of £50 notes and used her good looks to gain his trust. She received gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants from him. Granger and her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, along with an accomplice Nicholas Chandler, plotted to lure Hassan to his flat under the pretense of a romantic encounter. Police have discontinued an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite having a video and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of suspected saboteurs. The assault occurred when Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters wielding iron bars on ropes while the hunt was chasing an artificial scent, not a fox. Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a U.S. citizen who became a prominent English-language propagandist for al-Qaeda. He was born in 1978 to a Jewish family in California, converted to Islam in 1995, and left the U.S. for Pakistan in 1999. Gadahn was not specifically targeted but was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. He was not one of al-Qaeda's top leaders but was known for his numerous statements on behalf of the organization, including threats against Los Angeles and Melbourne, Australia. He was indicted for treason and material support to al-Qaeda in 2006 and appeared in videos criticizing U.S. presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama. His final video was posted in 2014, calling for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. Gadahn was married to a Muslim woman and reportedly had a child.

The passage describes the phenomenon of Chinese parents fostering child prodigies, highlighting a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo who has become a viral sensation for his exceptional basketball skills. The passage describes Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the notorious paedophile information exchange (PIE), which advocated for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s. The passage describes an unusual event at Bondi's Icebergs Club where the pool, a beloved spot for lap swimmers, was drained to serve as a catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event took place on a warm day, with guests enjoying the sunshine and icebergs-served nibbles and drinks. The passage highlights the fusion of fashion and the local beach culture at Bondi, with the pool serving as a striking backdrop to the minimalist and androgynous designs.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent his Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in northern California with his family. Khan had been under pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook in June but stated he was in negotiations for another opponent. Khan's previous potential opponents included Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman, but he has now confirmed his May 30th fight against Algieri.

The passage discusses the removal of a Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His family and an organization representing victims of terror in Israel objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, the site of the national cemetery, as Israel prepared to mark its memorial day. The family and the organization argued that Abu Khdeir's death was a rogue attack and not a terror act, and they demanded that his name be removed from the memorial. Following their complaints, the national insurance institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, decided to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the wall. The name has also been removed from the organization's website listing the names on the memorial wall. A panel of judges began hearing evidence in January against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing.

The passage describes a humorous scene where a young boy attempts to use his cat's belly as a pillow to rest his head. The footage captures the cat initially sitting and licking its fur before the boy plops down on top of it. The cat, after a brief moment of stillness, quickly gets up and moves to another spot, prompting the boy to follow and repeat the process. This chase-and-rest routine happens a couple of times before the cat decides it's had enough and goes indoors. The passage discusses a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, where Robert Kushner, a witness, has lost his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. The passage describes an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, which produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical used in the production of polyester films and fabrics. The explosion occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak and resulted in six injuries, all from broken glass, with five individuals being hospitalized for treatment. Over 600 firefighters were dispatched to control the blaze, which has since been brought under control. Residents near the plant reported hearing the explosion and shared photos of the fire on social media. The plant has experienced another explosion in July 2013, but there were no reported casualties or toxic leaks at that time. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests in several Chinese cities due to pollution concerns, leading to some plants being relocated to more remote areas. The Zhangzhou plant was originally planned to be situated in Xiamen, a densely populated city, but was moved due to public backlash over pollution issues in 2007.

The passage discusses Jack Grealish, a teenager playing for Aston Villa in the Premier League, and his unique superstition regarding his socks and shinpads. Grealish is known for wearing his socks just above the roll of his shinpads, a practice he attributes to superstition and has maintained throughout his life. Despite attempts by referees to persuade him to change his style, Grealish remains committed to his tradition.

The passage highlights that Grealish's appearance might initially suggest he does not wear shinpads, but he actually uses children's-sized shinpads. This choice is not about comfort or practicality but is purely due to his superstition.

Grealish made his first Premier League start for Aston Villa against Queens Park Rangers (QPR) on Tuesday, which ended in a 3-3 draw. The passage describes the critical condition of Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston. According to her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and a source with knowledge of her condition, Bobbi Kristina has "global and irreversible brain damage." Despite being no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. Her eyes do not follow people around the room, and she has a tracheostomy in her throat.

Contrary to these reports, Bobbi Kristina's father, Bobby Brown, claimed in a public statement that she had improved and was awake, watching him. The conflicting statements from family members highlight the emotional turmoil and uncertainty surrounding Bobbi Kristina's condition and future.

Russia is on the verge of clinching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki in three sets. Svetlana Kuznetsova also secured a straight-set win over Julia Görges in the opening match. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful game, committing 13 double faults but ultimately won due to Lisicki's 63 unforced errors. Pavlyuchenkova commented on Lisicki's aggressive style, saying, "In the first set, I believed I could win but I couldn't find the rhythm because she plays a bit boom-boom." With the current score, Russia needs just one more win on Sunday to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned about potential flooding and damage due to another storm predicted to hit later this week. The warning comes after an east coast low, the same weather system that caused severe weather last week, is indicated to return. This system could bring heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) was overwhelmed with calls for assistance last week and still has over 4,000 jobs to complete from 24,196 requests. The SES is particularly concerned about the Hunter region, which was hard-hit by the last storm, fearing that more rain will raise flood levels and wind will knock over already uprooted trees. The SES is urging the community to prepare for the possibility of more wild weather to prevent further loss and devastation. Meteorologists say the weather system, while similar to last week's, is expected to be a little further from the coast and in a different area, meaning Sydney might not experience the same heavy rain. However, they predict two days of rain, with the peak expected between Thursday and Saturday. The Bureau of Meteorology's NSW Regional Director, Barry Hanstrum, stated that rain is expected to increase this week, with heavy falls likely for the northern rivers and mid north coast

The passage discusses Nina Moric, a model who gained attention after posting photos on Instagram showing heavy bruising on her arms. However, Moric quickly took to social media to deny these claims, stating that she was treated in the hospital due to a fall at home, which caused her to suffer from low blood pressure. The incident occurred on Saturday night, and she clarified that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident, contradicting earlier reports that he was present during the alleged suicide attempt.

Moric also addressed the media's claim that she had previously attempted suicide in 2009, stating that this was not true. The passage discusses public anticipation for the name of the second child of Kate and William, with a strong preference for the name Diana if the baby is a girl. A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding dozens more. The passage discusses James Haskell, an England rugby player, who dressed up as Iron Man from the Avengers movie for an Instagram post. The passage discusses the wide leg trouser trend that is emerging in SS15. It highlights that wide leg trousers come in various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, and striped. The trend is described as effortless and offers an alternative to the popular skinny jeans. Louise Redknapp mentions that wide-leg trousers can be a relief from the skinny jean, and although they have made a comeback since the 70s, they can be intimidating for shorter individuals. The University of Michigan initially decided to cancel the screening of the film "American Sniper" due to objections from over 200 students who believed the movie portrayed the Middle East and its people negatively. Two French tourists set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, a small marsupial resembling a rat-kangaroo, was singed but survived the incident. The men, aged 18 and 24, were questioned by detectives and charged with animal cruelty. They were living in Cockburn Central and were evicted from the island. They are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are native to Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany, and they are about the size of a domestic cat.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old woman, was a dancer in the 1930s and 1940s at nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar. She danced alongside famous performers such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. She had never seen any of the motion pictures made of her and had lost all her photographs and memorabilia over the years, so she had never seen herself dance. Mark Cantor and volunteers from jazz-on-film.com compiled a video of "soundies," which are early music videos, and showed it to her in her nursing home. Barker was thrilled, exclaiming, "It's just fabulous!"

The passage discusses the decline of washing cars by hand, a tradition that used to be a part of many British Sunday routines. The reasons cited for this decline include the availability of car washes on local forecourts, the rise of hand car washes, the size of modern 4x4 and off-road vehicles, and the increased availability of entertainment options on Sundays, such as live football on TV, which delays or cancels the chore. The Easter break saw an increase in car washing as a means for people to get out of the house. The survey found that car washing is most frequent in cities like Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, while it is least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most often washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least likely to be washed by hand. The passage discusses Martin Skrtel's admiration for Steven Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, who is set to leave the club after the current season. Skrtel, who has been at Liverpool since 2008, credits Gerrard with helping him settle at the club. Gerrard is aiming to end his Liverpool career by leading the team to the FA Cup final against Arsenal, which would coincide with his birthday on May 30.

Skrtel believes that Gerrard is synonymous with Liverpool and one of the best players in the world. Despite some initial struggles upon arriving in England, Skrtel has become a key player in Liverpool's defense. He appreciates Gerrard's support during his early days at the club.

Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, but he is confident that the club has the players capable of filling his void, provided they receive the necessary support. Both players could return to the Liverpool lineup for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.
