Jack Nicklaus, at the age of 75, achieved a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, his shot on the 130-yard fourth hole sailing beyond the flag and spinning back into the hole. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, and his ace was the first on Augusta's hallowed turf for him. Nicklaus, often referred to as the "Golden Bear," has a storied career, having won a record 18 major championships. He became the youngest Masters champion in 1963 and won his sixth Masters in 1986. Nicklaus is one of five golfers to complete the career Grand Slam, which Rory McIlroy could achieve by winning his third consecutive major. However, on the day of Nicklaus's ace, Camilo Villegas also achieved three hole-in-ones, tying the record set in 2002, although he ultimately lost the par-3 contest to Kevin Streelman.

The passage describes a series of tornadoes that occurred on Wednesday night in Kansas and reports of tornado activity in Missouri. Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, Kansas, which moved northeast and missed Wichita but posed a risk to other communities. Chad Myers, a CNN severe weather expert, emphasized the danger of nighttime tornadoes. There were additional reports of tornadoes in southwestern Kansas near Aetna, about 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado in the small town of Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. CNN affiliates reported wind damage and flooding in Potosi, Missouri, with an Instagram user sharing a photo of a fallen tree. Aerial footage showed damage to roofs and streets overtaken by water. Further east, in the vicinity of Shyler and Christin Strube in Leadington, Missouri, dark clouds were captured on Instagram. In Farmington, Missouri, Kevin Knox experienced baseball-sized hail when he went out to his car. On Thursday, more storms are expected in specific regions of the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes, according to the National Weather Service.

The passage describes the legal proceedings against Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy accused of fatally shooting Eric Harris during a sting operation. Bates has pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter. The judge allowed Bates to go on vacation to the Bahamas, which the Harris family found insensitive given the circumstances of the shooting. The preliminary hearing for Bates is scheduled for July 2. The family's attorney criticized Bates for going on vacation, suggesting it showed apathy. Bates claims the shooting was accidental, and both he and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized to the Harris family. Allegations have been made that Bates was not qualified to be a deputy and received preferential treatment due to donations and personal connections. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has denied these allegations. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats. Bates's lawyers released training documents to prove he had the necessary law enforcement training. CNN reporters Jason Morris and Ed Lavandera contributed to the report.

Conor McGregor has unveiled a new tiger face tattoo on his stomach, writing next to the Instagram post, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor is gearing up for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He claims Aldo lacks the same motivation as him to fight, stating, "He does n't want to be near me, he doesn't want this the way I want it." McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during their promotional tour in Dublin in March, asserting his desire to win the title. The fight in Las Vegas will be Aldo's eighth defense of his belt, and McGregor is determined to defeat him and claim the championship.

The passage describes an incident where Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules football function, which has sparked criticism from anti-drinking campaigners. They argue that by engaging in this act, Abbott is glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with excessive alcohol consumption. Julie Roberts, a cultural studies professor, expresses concern that this behavior sets a cultural norm where drinking is about quantity and speed rather than socializing.

The event took place on a Saturday night, with Abbott downing a schooner of beer in about six seconds to the cheers of a crowd of about 50. Critics, including Roberts, argue that such behavior by public figures, especially those in leadership positions, can encourage irresponsible drinking and perpetuate the stereotype that being a true blue Aussie involves heavy drinking.

Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, suggesting that if more people exercised as much as he does, the country would be healthier. During his speech, Abbott joked about finally getting to hang out with real footballers, which was met with enthusiasm from the crowd.

The passage also mentions that while previous prime ministers, like Bob Hawke, have been known for their skolling skills, Roberts believes Abbott should be mindful

The passage discusses an increase in HIV cases in Indiana, specifically in Scott County, which has seen a significant rise in confirmed and preliminary positive HIV cases since a short-term needle exchange program was initiated by Governor Mike Pence on March 26. The program was created in response to what health officials have declared as an epidemic. Initially, there were 106 confirmed cases, and this number has risen to 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, indicating a substantial increase. The outbreak is linked to intravenous drug users and the use of Opana, a high-powered painkiller. The program has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used syringes for disposal. Brittany Combs, a public health nurse, highlights the importance of trust in the community for the program's success.

The future of the needle exchange program, including whether it will be extended beyond its current April 25 deadline, is uncertain. Governor Pence is reviewing reports and recommendations from health officials and is expected to make a decision early next week. The passage also touches on legislative efforts, with a bill sponsored by House Public Health Committee Chairman Ed Clere that would allow needle-exchange programs in other counties

The test included multiple-choice questions, filling in tables, and an 'in your own words' section. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50, which impressed her boyfriend enough to refrain from dumping her, jokingly saying, "Lucky you."

Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for U.S. citizenship. After declining health forced him to retire, he is now facing deportation despite his invaluable contributions to the DEA, which included aiding in the capture of Carlos Lehder Rivas and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. The DEA reneged on its promise of citizenship, leaving Toro in a precarious legal and health situation. He fears returning to Colombia due to the danger, stating, "I am scared to death. I do not sleep anymore. I am only thinking about what happens if they come for me." Toro's work has led to the prosecution of significant drug figures, yet he is now without legal status, unable to secure a green card, passport, or social security benefits. A former colleague helped him with $5,000 for an operation after the DEA refused, highlighting the bureaucratic issues he faces. The passage describes Open Garden's FireChat app and their new device, Greenstone. FireChat allows users to chat without a web or mobile signal by creating a wireless mesh network using Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF), which is available in iOS 7 and has a similar feature in Android over Bluetooth. The app connects users within a 30-foot (9 meters) radius, forming a local network where each phone acts as a node. Messages are sent securely and anonymously, and the 'everyone' chatroom allows messages to be relayed over longer distances by connecting multiple nodes.

Greenstone is an egg-shaped device designed to boost these mesh networks, enabling messages to travel further than the typical 200-foot (61 meters) limit. It acts as a beacon, increasing the range and reliability of the network. The device can hold up to 1,000 messages and has a one-year battery life. Open Garden is working with manufacturers to bring Greenstone to market, with the potential for it to be used in various scenarios where reliable communication is essential, such as at music festivals, protests, or in areas with poor connectivity.

In summary, FireChat and Greenstone together enable a decentralized communication network

The largest single high-definition map of dark matter has been produced, marking the first step in a series of maps that will eventually provide a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. This map, created by researchers at the University of Manchester, uses data from the Dark Energy Camera (DECam) on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile. The map shows clumps of dark matter across 0.4% of the sky, with red indicating higher concentrations and blue indicating lower concentrations. The ultimate goal is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years.

Dark matter is a mysterious substance that makes up about 85% of the universe's matter and affects the rotation of galaxies and gravitational forces without emitting or blocking light. It was discovered through its gravitational effects on visible matter. The Dark Energy Survey (DES) is a five-year project that aims to map dark matter and dark energy across a significant portion of the sky.

The map was made by analyzing 130 million separate images of galaxies taken by the telescope. The process is complex and requires the use of some of the world's largest supercomputers to measure the shapes and distortions of galaxies with high precision.
